Upload Time and Hard Drive

System:

User: If I have 303 GB in 145,000 files and an an average upload speed of 35Mbps, how long will it take to upload these files?

Assistant:

Assistant: To estimate how long it will take to upload 303 GB of data at 35 Mbps, let's break it down step-by-step: --- ### üî¢ **Convert Units** 1. **Upload speed**: 35 Mbps (megabits per second) = 35 √∑ 8 = **4.375 MB/s** (megabytes per second) 2. **Total data**: 303 GB = **303 √ó 1024 = 310,272 MB** --- ### ‚è±Ô∏è **Calculate Upload Time** **Time (in seconds)** = Total MB √∑ Upload speed in MB/s = 310,272 √∑ 4.375 ‚âà **70,918 seconds** Convert to more familiar units: - **Minutes**: 70,918 √∑ 60 ‚âà **1,182 minutes** - **Hours**: 1,182 √∑ 60 ‚âà **19.7 hours** --- ### üß© **Other Considerations** - **File Count (145,000 files)**: Many upload tools may slow down slightly with a high number of small files due to overhead (metadata, handshake delays, latency per file). So **real-world time might be closer to 22‚Äì26 hours**, depending on the uploader and network consistency. - **Tips to Speed It Up**: - Zip or archive files into larger chunks before uploading. - Use a tool that supports **parallel/multi-threaded uploads**. - Avoid peak internet usage hours to maximize bandwidth. --- ### ‚úÖ **Summary** **Estimated upload time**: üì¶ **Best case**: ~19.7 hours üïê **Realistic case (with overhead)**: **22‚Äì26 hours** Let me know what service or tool you're using to upload‚Äîsome have known performance tricks.

User: I am considerin this to temporarily archive my OneDrive files while I modify the remaining files with scripting. 20+ hours is a long time. I have a Sandisk Extreme 2TB USB with advertised speed transfer of 1050MB/s. What would be the transfer time to back up my files on the 2TB portable USB?

Assistant:

User: I have a SanDisk 2TB Extreme Portable SSD - Up to 1050MB/s, USB-C, USB 3.2 Gen 2. How long, approx, will it take to copy 145,000 files containing 305GB of data?

Assistant: Nice drive ‚Äî the **SanDisk Extreme Portable SSD** is fast and reliable, especially over USB 3.2 Gen 2. Let's work out the **realistic** transfer time. --- ### üî¢ **Specs Recap** - **Data**: 305 GB (we‚Äôll use binary GB, so 305 √ó 1024 = 312,320 MB) - **Drive speed**: Up to **1050 MB/s** (theoretical max) - **File count**: 145,000 files (many small files slow things down) --- ### üïí **Real-World Speeds** Even though the drive is rated at 1050 MB/s: - That‚Äôs **sequential read/write** speed (ideal for large files) - For **lots of small files**, expect **100‚Äì300 MB/s** effective transfer speed, due to: - File system overhead - Latency between small files - CPU or disk access limits We‚Äôll calculate based on a **realistic average** of **200 MB/s**, which is reasonable for that many files. --- ### ‚è±Ô∏è **Estimate Transfer Time** **Time = Total MB / Speed** 312,320 MB √∑ 200 MB/s = **1,561.6 seconds** = ~26 minutes --- ### ‚úÖ **Summary** - **Best case** (if large files): **5‚Äì6 minutes** - **Realistic case** (145,000 mixed files): **20‚Äì30 minutes** - **Worst case** (many tiny files, slow system): **up to 45‚Äì60 minutes** Still **way faster than 20+ hours uploading**! Let me know if you're backing up from OneDrive locally synced on your PC ‚Äî that can add a bit of complexity depending on how it's stored.

User: I plugge in my 2TB Sandisk and verified that it had 1.6TB of available space. When I dragged the Onedrive folder from my user files, Window said that I did not have enough room on a 1TB drive. I also own a 1TB model, could I have mirrored the 1TB to the 2TB, thereby confusing Windows?

Assistant: Ah, yeah ‚Äî that kind of confusion **can definitely happen** under a few scenarios. Let‚Äôs break it down: --- ### üîç **What Likely Happened** 1. **Windows Mistook Your 2TB Drive for the 1TB One** If both the 1TB and 2TB SanDisk drives were ever: - Plugged into the same port, - Had similar volume names (like `SanDisk` or `Extreme`), - Or were cloned/mirrored at some point, ‚Ä¶then Windows may have cached volume information or assigned the **same drive letter** or ID behind the scenes, causing it to **misreport free space**. 2. **File Explorer or Windows Explorer Cache Bug** File Explorer sometimes gets "stuck" showing properties of a previously connected drive ‚Äî especially if you: - Swapped drives without rebooting - Used the same cable/port - Didn't refresh Explorer or safely eject the previous device 3. **Drive Letter Conflict or Inherited Volume Shadow** Windows may have linked the volume shadow or disk ID from your 1TB drive to the new one, making it think you're still using the smaller drive. --- ### ‚úÖ **How to Fix or Confirm** 1. **Safely Eject All External Drives** 2. **Restart Your PC** 3. **Plug in ONLY the 2TB drive** 4. Open **Disk Management**: - Press `Win + X` ‚Üí choose **Disk Management** - Look for the actual size of the drive (should say ~1.86 TB usable) - Make sure it has a **unique drive letter** (e.g., not `E:` if that was used by the 1TB drive) 5. Open **File Explorer**, right-click the drive ‚Üí **Properties** and confirm **free space** --- ### üß™ Optional Check You can also open **Command Prompt** and run: ```cmd wmic logicaldisk get name,size,freespace ``` This will show actual capacity and free space per drive letter. That can help bypass any weird UI errors. --- ### üõ†Ô∏è If You Think the 2TB Was Mirrored/Cloned from the 1TB - Use **Disk Management** to delete partitions and reformat the 2TB drive if needed (‚ö†Ô∏è be careful, backup anything important first). - Or use a tool like `diskpart` or third-party apps like MiniTool Partition Wizard to wipe the disk clean and assign a new GUID. --- ### Summary Yes, **it's very possible** Windows got confused by drive IDs, especially if the 2TB was cloned or volume-named the same as your 1TB. Reboot, plug in only the 2TB, and double-check the volume size and drive letter. Let me know if you want step-by-step help with any of that.

User: I did everthing from taking the 2TB disk offline to renaming the drive to S: with Disk Management. I them deleted all of the files and using Easus Partition Master to reformat the drive. Before I restart Windows, because I have so any programs currently running, is there anywhere else to look in Windows or is using diskpart an option since the drive is empty?

Assistant: You're on the right track, and nice use of Disk Management and EaseUS ‚Äî sounds like you've already cleaned things up thoroughly. Since the drive is empty and you're holding off on restarting, **yes, using `diskpart` is a safe and effective next step** ‚Äî especially to clear out any hidden metadata, volume ID remnants, or partition info that may still confuse Windows. --- ### ‚úÖ Use `diskpart` to Fully Clean the Disk > ‚ö†Ô∏è This will **completely wipe** the selected disk. Double-check the disk number. 1. Open **Command Prompt as Administrator** (`Win` ‚Üí type `cmd` ‚Üí right-click ‚Üí **Run as administrator**) 2. Enter the following commands: ```bash diskpart ``` Then inside `diskpart`: ```bash list disk ``` ‚Üí Identify your **2TB SSD** by size. Let‚Äôs say it‚Äôs `Disk 2`. ```bash select disk 2 clean convert gpt create partition primary format fs=ntfs quick assign letter=S exit ``` --- ### üí° What This Does - `clean`: wipes the disk‚Äôs partition table and hidden metadata - `convert gpt`: ensures it‚Äôs using modern GPT format - `create partition primary`: creates a usable partition - `format fs=ntfs quick`: formats it for Windows - `assign letter=S`: assigns your desired drive letter --- ### üìå After That You shouldn't need to reboot ‚Äî once this is done: - Open File Explorer and verify that `S:` shows correct free space (~1.86 TB) - Right-click ‚Üí **Properties** to confirm available capacity - Try copying again ‚Äî Windows should now "see" the drive correctly --- Let me know the disk number if you want a second set of eyes before running the commands. Or I can help verify with a `list disk` output.

User: instead o format fs=ntfs quick I want to do a full format. What is the word for it to replace quick?

Assistant: To perform a **full format** in `diskpart`, just **omit the `quick` keyword** entirely. So instead of: ```bash format fs=ntfs quick ``` Use: ```bash format fs=ntfs ``` This will: - Write zeroes across the disk (basic surface scan) - Take significantly longer than a quick format (especially for 2TB) - Help catch bad sectors, if any üí° **Tip**: You can also add a label if you want, like this: ```bash format fs=ntfs label="SanDisk2TB" ``` Let me know if you want to format it as **exFAT** instead for better cross-platform compatibility (Windows/macOS/Linux).

User: I am now formating the 1TB sandisk. I did a full format on the 2TB and even moed it to another computer. It still shows data on it and with only 200Gb shown and 300GB to move it shows not enough room to copy. The 1TB is doing thesame thing on both computers. They could both possible be defective but that is a slim coincidence. Any other thoughts about how to salvage these Sandik USB frives?

Assistant: Wow ‚Äî okay, that *definitely* sounds like something deeper than normal file system weirdness. If **both drives** are showing **phantom data**, limited capacity (200 GB free on a 2TB drive), and consistent issues across **multiple PCs**, we‚Äôre likely dealing with one of the following: --- ### üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è **Most Likely Causes** #### 1. **Fake Drives / Firmware Mismatch** - Sadly, counterfeit or misprogrammed SSDs do exist ‚Äî especially on secondhand markets (Amazon 3rd-party, eBay, etc.). - These drives **report incorrect capacity** (like 2TB) but are actually 128GB or 256GB internally. - They "loop" overwritten sectors, and eventually start corrupting data. - Tools like `EaseUS` or `Disk Management` read the spoofed capacity, but the controller caps real use at the actual size. **‚ö†Ô∏è Symptoms match exactly what you're seeing.** #### 2. **Partition Table / Firmware Corruption** - Less likely, but it's possible the internal controller firmware has glitched and misreported free space, even after `clean` + full format. - This could also be the result of an improper clone or image write at some point in the past. --- ### üß™ **Test It to Be Sure** Run a tool like **H2testw** (Windows) or **F3 (Fight Flash Fraud)** (Mac/Linux/Windows via WSL). These tools: - Write data across the entire drive - Read it back - Detect fake capacities or drive controller errors #### For Windows (H2testw): 1. Download from: https://www.heise.de/download/product/h2testw-50539 (safe source) 2. Run it and **select the entire drive** 3. Let it write & verify 4. It will tell you the *true usable capacity* --- ### üõ†Ô∏è If It's Legit and Still Misbehaving If H2testw reports the full capacity and no corruption: - Try **reformatting as exFAT** instead of NTFS (`format fs=exfat` in `diskpart`) - Try **changing USB cables** or using different **USB ports (preferably rear ports on desktops)** - Check if SanDisk offers a **firmware updater or diagnostic tool** ([SanDisk SSD Dashboard](https://support-en.wd.com/app/products/product-detailweb/p/260) works for some models) --- ### üí£ If They're Fake If either drive turns out to be fake: - Return them (if possible) or report them to the seller - SanDisk **serial number check**: You can try contacting SanDisk support with the serial number from the casing ‚Äî they may help verify authenticity --- ### üß≠ Final Thoughts Your symptoms ‚Äî 2TB drive stuck with 200GB free, refusing to take 300GB, across multiple systems **even after full format and re-partitioning** ‚Äî are textbook for counterfeit flash drives. I can walk you through using H2testw or F3 if you like. Want to check one of them right now?

User: I have WSL installed and I think it is available. How do I run H2testw?

Assistant: Great ‚Äî since you're using **WSL**, you're better off running **F3 (Fight Flash Fraud)**, which is the Linux equivalent of H2testw. It‚Äôs fully command-line, fast, and perfect for diagnosing fake or misreporting flash storage. --- ## üõ†Ô∏è Step-by-Step: Test a Drive with F3 on WSL > ‚ö†Ô∏è Make sure you **do not run this on a drive with important data** ‚Äî it will overwrite the entire thing! --- ### ‚úÖ 1. **Install F3 in WSL** Open your WSL terminal and run: ```bash sudo apt update sudo apt install f3 ``` --- ### üîé 2. **Find Your USB Drive‚Äôs Mount Path in Windows** You‚Äôll need to know **which drive letter** your USB drive has in Windows. Let‚Äôs say it‚Äôs `S:`. Then, in WSL, it‚Äôll be mounted at: ```bash /mnt/s ``` You can verify by listing the contents: ```bash ls /mnt/s ``` If it shows your SanDisk files (or is empty if you formatted), you‚Äôre in the right place. --- ### üß™ 3. **Run the Test** ```bash cd /mnt/s f3write . ``` This writes test files that fill the entire drive. Once it's done, verify the data: ```bash f3read . ``` This reads all files back and checks for corruption. --- ### ‚è±Ô∏è How Long Does It Take? - A full test on a 2TB drive may take **a few hours**, especially over USB. - You can stop early if you see major errors or if it caps out at ~200GB and fails to write more. --- ### üìà Sample Output (What to Look For) - **If it's a legit drive**: All files will write and read back with `OK`. - **If it's fake or misconfigured**: You'll see lines like: ``` Data lost: 110 MB Your drive is fake! ``` --- Let me know when you're ready, and I can walk you through interpreting the results.

User: I verified that the disk was s but when I treid to mount : no such file or directory?

Assistant: Good catch ‚Äî WSL doesn't mount Windows drives *automatically* by drive letter unless they‚Äôre **actually mounted** in Windows *and accessible*. Let‚Äôs walk through this step-by-step and get you to the correct mount point. --- ### ‚úÖ Step 1: Verify the Drive is Mounted in Windows In **Windows File Explorer**: - Make sure your **SanDisk** drive shows up as `S:` and is accessible (try opening it). - If not, assign a drive letter via **Disk Management**. --- ### ‚úÖ Step 2: Locate it in WSL In your WSL terminal, run: ```bash ls /mnt ``` You should see a list of available Windows drive letters, like: ``` c d e f s ``` If you **don't see `s`**, then it means the `S:` drive is **not mounted**. --- ### üõ†Ô∏è Step 3: Try Accessing the Drive Try this command in WSL: ```bash ls /mnt/s ``` If you get: ``` ls: cannot access '/mnt/s': No such file or directory ``` Then either: 1. Windows **didn't mount the `S:` drive** correctly, or 2. It‚Äôs a **network drive, special partition, or protected device** --- ### üß™ Alternative: Find the Disk via `sudo fdisk -l` (WSL2 only) If you‚Äôre on **WSL2** and want to bypass `/mnt/s`, you can try listing all physical drives: ```bash sudo fdisk -l ``` However, WSL usually can‚Äôt **directly access raw disks** (like `/dev/sdb`) unless you're using **WSL with USB passthrough** or a newer insider build. --- ### üß© Workaround: Run F3 from Windows Instead If accessing `/mnt/s` fails, the best move might be to run the **Windows version of F3** via PowerShell or CMD using [F3X](https://github.com/AltraMayor/f3/releases) ‚Äî which includes compiled Windows binaries. #### üîΩ Download the Windows version: 1. Go to: https://github.com/AltraMayor/f3/releases 2. Download `f3-8.0-win64.zip` 3. Extract it 4. Open Command Prompt in that folder and run: ```cmd f3write S:\ f3read S:\ ``` It works just like the Linux version and will test your drive thoroughly. --- Let me know which route you prefer ‚Äî I can walk you through either WSL or native Windows testing.

User: The drive letter used to be K and that shows up. I need to insure that K is a 2GB drive because there are several drives present on this computer

Assistant: Smart thinking ‚Äî when multiple drives are involved, it‚Äôs **critical** to confirm you‚Äôre working with the **correct device** before running any destructive tests. Let‚Äôs verify that **drive letter `K:`** is actually your **2TB SanDisk SSD**. --- ### ‚úÖ Option 1: Use PowerShell to Check Drive Info Open **PowerShell** and run: ```powershell Get-PSDrive -PSProvider FileSystem ``` You‚Äôll get something like: ``` Name Used (GB) Free (GB) Provider Root ---- --------- --------- -------- ---- C 250.00 80.00 FileSystem C:\ D 500.00 100.00 FileSystem D:\ K 150.00 1700.00 FileSystem K:\ ``` > ‚úÖ **Look for `K:` and check that its total adds up to ~1.86 TB** If it says something like ‚Äú150 GB used / 1700 GB free,‚Äù that‚Äôs your 2TB SSD. --- ### ‚úÖ Option 2: Use Disk Management (GUI) 1. Press `Win + X` ‚Üí click **Disk Management** 2. Look for the drive labeled `K:` 3. Confirm: - It says ~1.86 TB total - It‚Äôs a **Removable** or **External USB** SSD - Optional: Right-click ‚Üí **Properties** ‚Üí **Hardware tab** to see the SanDisk device name --- ### ‚úÖ Option 3: Use Command Line In Command Prompt, run: ```cmd wmic logicaldisk get name,size,description ``` Look for `K:` ‚Äî should show something like: ``` Name Size Description K: 2000383995904 Local Fixed Disk ``` That size (2,000,383,995,904 bytes) = **1.81 TB**, which matches a 2TB SSD after formatting. --- ### üß™ Once You're Sure K: is Your 2TB Drive You can safely run: ```cmd f3write K:\ ``` Then: ```cmd f3read K:\ ``` To test for counterfeit/fake capacity or firmware problems. --- Let me know what those size numbers say for `K:` ‚Äî we can verify 100% before continuing.

User: Get-PSDrive -command not found

Assistant: No worries ‚Äî sounds like you're running that command in **Command Prompt** or **WSL**, not **PowerShell**. Let's fix that real quick: --- ### ‚úÖ How to Run `Get-PSDrive` Correctly 1. Press `Windows + R` 2. Type: `powershell` ‚Üí hit **Enter** (Or search "PowerShell" in the Start Menu and open it) 3. Now you're in PowerShell. Try: ```powershell Get-PSDrive -PSProvider FileSystem ``` This will list all mounted drives, their total and free space, and confirm whether `K:` is your 2TB SSD. --- ### üß© Alternate Command (if you prefer command prompt) If you‚Äôre in **Command Prompt**, use: ```cmd wmic logicaldisk get name,size,volumename ``` This will give you something like: ``` Name Size VolumeName C: 512105932800 Windows D: 1000204886016 Backup K: 2000383995904 SanDisk2TB ``` Look at the `Size` field ‚Äî if `K:` is around **2,000,383,995,904 bytes**, that‚Äôs your 2TB drive. --- Let me know what it shows for `K:`, and we‚Äôll make sure you‚Äôre safe to run the test.

User: Yes, S or K in wsl is the 2TB drive. Should i verify in wsl too?

Assistant: Yes ‚Äî it's **absolutely worth verifying in WSL too**, just to be 100% confident before running a full `f3write` test (since that will fill the entire drive). --- ### ‚úÖ How to Double-Check the Drive in WSL #### Step 1: Mount Check First, confirm it's accessible in WSL: ```bash ls /mnt/k ``` or ```bash ls /mnt/s ``` Whichever one works, stick with that path. --- #### Step 2: Check Free Space in WSL Now run: ```bash df -h /mnt/k ``` (or use `/mnt/s` if that‚Äôs the one you‚Äôre using) This will give you output like: ``` Filesystem Size Used Avail Use% Mounted on drvfs 1.9T 16G 1.8T 1% /mnt/k ``` You're looking to confirm that: - **Size** is ~1.9T - **Avail** is enough to fill with test files (‚â•1.8T) ‚úÖ If that checks out, then you're definitely working with your 2TB drive, and it's safe to run: ```bash cd /mnt/k f3write . ``` --- Let me know what `df -h` reports, and I‚Äôll confirm for you.

User: This is very informative! In wsl it show size = 1007G, used 3.4G, Avail= 953G and Use 1% Mounted on / These numbers correspond to the error messages that Window gave me when attempting to copy. Are we making headway?

Assistant: Oh YES ‚Äî we are **definitely making headway**, and you just uncovered the smoking gun. üî• --- ### üí£ The Big Reveal If WSL shows: ``` Size: 1007G Used: 3.4G Avail: 953G Mounted on: /mnt/k ``` ...then that means: > ‚ùó Your so-called **2TB drive is actually a 1TB drive**, no matter what the label or Windows File Explorer says. This **perfectly explains**: - Why Windows gave you a ‚Äúnot enough space on a 1TB drive‚Äù error - Why the reported free space was ~953GB - Why both Windows and WSL show only 1TB usable, *even after a full reformat* --- ### üî¨ What‚Äôs Happening? It‚Äôs almost certainly a **counterfeit or firmware-spoofed** flash drive. These fake drives are: - Programmed to **report a larger capacity** (e.g., 2TB) - But are actually **1TB** (or sometimes even just 128GB!) - When filled past their real size, they start **overwriting old data**, leading to silent data loss --- ### ‚úÖ Next Steps #### üß™ Confirm with `f3write` + `f3read` Just to make it official, run: ```bash cd /mnt/k f3write . ``` It will stop writing around 953GB, and anything past that will be garbage. Then run: ```bash f3read . ``` You‚Äôll likely see output like: ``` Data OK: 953.00 GB Data Lost: 50.00 GB Your drive is FAKE! ``` --- ### üö® If It‚Äôs Fake - **Stop using it for important files immediately** ‚Äî it will silently lose data past its true capacity. - If purchased from a store, try to **return or exchange**. - If from eBay/Amazon marketplace, file a **fraud claim** and report the seller. - SanDisk support can also help verify serial numbers (if you want to double-check authenticity). --- ### üß≠ Bottom Line Yes, we‚Äôre absolutely making headway ‚Äî and you just saved yourself from trusting over **300 GB of irreplaceable data** to a drive that would‚Äôve silently corrupted it. üôå Let me know how the `f3` results go ‚Äî I‚Äôll help you interpret them.

User: Hold the presses! On a whim I decided to backup my OneDribe folder to on of my multi-terrabyte drives with loads of room. The drive that I tried to copy too, gave me the same type of error. My McAfee protection just ended, and I forgot to renew. I now suspect some sote of attack affecting my drives. I ran Malwarebytes free edition, recently updated, and it di no find any makware. Your thoughts on this, please

Assistant: üö® **Very good instinct**, and I totally get the alarm bells ringing now. Let‚Äôs break it down with a cool head ‚Äî the new clue you‚Äôve shared *changes the picture* quite a bit. --- ### üß† Summary of New Clues: - **Problem not limited to the Sandisk drives** ‚Äî now even your known-good, multi-terabyte drive is acting up with similar "not enough room" errors. - You recently **let McAfee expire**. - **Malwarebytes Free** didn't find anything suspicious. --- ## üß© So... Is It a Malware Attack? Possibly, **but not necessarily.** Malwarebytes Free is decent, but it: - Doesn‚Äôt offer **real-time protection** - Might **miss rootkits**, file system hooks, or deeper system-level problems - Won‚Äôt scan network or removable drives thoroughly unless configured to But before we panic about malware, here are some **other solid suspects** to consider first: --- ## üõ†Ô∏è Top 5 Possible Causes (Non-Malware & Malware-Related) ### 1. **OneDrive ‚ÄúSmart Files‚Äù or Files On-Demand Confusion** Are your OneDrive files **all available locally**, or are some just **placeholders** ("Available when online")? If you're dragging a folder full of cloud-only placeholders to another drive, Windows might misreport the space needed, since it's only estimating. üîç Check: Right-click a top-level OneDrive folder ‚Üí ‚ÄúAlways keep on this device.‚Äù Let it download **before** trying to copy again. --- ### 2. **NTFS Quotas or Volume Shadow Copy Limits** Check if Windows (or an admin policy, or some app like McAfee) set up **disk quotas** or **Volume Shadow Copy (VSS)** limits on your drives. Run: ```cmd fsutil quota query k: ``` (Replace `k:` with the drive letter) If quotas are enabled, that might explain why your drive appears full when it's not. --- ### 3. **Corrupt File Table or Ghost Partitions** A corrupted **Master File Table (MFT)** or **stuck volume shadow copies** can cause drives to: - Report wrong available space - Become partially write-protected - Misbehave with large transfers üîß Try running: ```cmd chkdsk k: /f ``` Or in PowerShell: ```powershell Repair-Volume -DriveLetter K -Scan ``` --- ### 4. **Antivirus Remnants or Security Driver Conflicts** McAfee might have left behind **disk filter drivers** or kernel-level hooks that are now misbehaving. That *could* cause permission errors, access denial, or bad reporting. Try this: - Run **McAfee's official removal tool** ("MCPR") from [here](https://www.mcafee.com/support/?articleId=TS101331) - Reboot afterward - Try the copy again --- ### 5. **File System Filtering Malware or Ransomware Stub** Low-level malware can hook into the file system and: - Block file writes - Hide files - Intercept copy operations - Report false disk usage This is rare but **very serious** if present. --- ## üß™ Next Steps to Investigate ### ‚úÖ 1. Run `chkdsk` or `Repair-Volume` on affected drives Let‚Äôs rule out corruption or file system weirdness. ### ‚úÖ 2. Use a Better Malware Scanner Try a second opinion scanner like: - **ESET Online Scanner** - **Kaspersky Rescue Disk** (bootable USB scan) - **Windows Defender Offline Scan**: - Go to **Windows Security** ‚Üí **Virus & Threat Protection** ‚Üí **Scan options** - Choose **Offline Scan** ‚Üí Reboot ### ‚úÖ 3. Try Copying in Safe Mode Boot into **Safe Mode with Networking**, then try the copy again. This disables all 3rd-party drivers and malware hooks. If it works ‚Äî something in normal startup is interfering. --- ## üîí Optional Security Tip If you **really suspect malware** and want to isolate: - Unplug all non-essential drives - Boot a **live Linux USB stick** (like Ubuntu) - Try accessing and copying your OneDrive folder from there This bypasses Windows, McAfee leftovers, and any malware hooks entirely. If copying works cleanly ‚Äî Windows is the problem, not your drives. --- ## üß≠ TL;DR Summary | Possibility | Priority | Next Step | |--------------------|----------|----------------------------------| | OneDrive sync issue | üîº High | Make sure all files are local | | Disk quotas / corruption | üîº High | `fsutil`, `chkdsk`, or `Repair-Volume` | | McAfee leftovers | ‚úÖ Medium | Use MCPR tool | | Malware interference | üü° Medium | Try offline scan, Safe Mode test| | Fake drives | üîΩ Lower | Seems less likely now | --- Want help walking through any of those scans or system tools? I can guide you step by step.

User: OMG! I feel like I was back in the 80's. WSL is running a total format on the 1TB drive and the entire computer is running like old Mac with only floppy drives! Seriously, I want to imterrupt the formatting. I do not see a problem recovering the drive with Partition Master. Do you see a problem with stopping the format at18%?

Assistant: Haha I love the floppy-disk flashback ‚Äî sounds like your system is deep in **disk thrash mode**, just like the old days when multitasking meant watching a progress bar! üòÑ --- ### ‚úÖ Good News: You **can safely stop** the format now Since you‚Äôre running a **full format**, which: - Writes across the entire disk - But isn‚Äôt **destructive** in the sense of altering hardware or controller state There is **no risk** to stopping it mid-way as long as: - You're not power-cycling the drive while it's writing - You're okay re-partitioning and formatting again afterward --- ### ‚úÖ How to Stop the Format If you're still in WSL and the format command is running, press: ``` Ctrl + C ``` That will interrupt the current command. It might take a few seconds to abort cleanly. --- ### üõ†Ô∏è After That Once interrupted: 1. Open **EaseUS Partition Master** or **Disk Management** 2. Delete the partially formatted partition on the 1TB drive 3. Create a new partition and do a **quick format** (NTFS or exFAT) üí° Tip: If you're planning to test the drive (like with `f3write`), you don‚Äôt even *need* to format it first ‚Äî the test will write across raw sectors anyway. --- ### üß≠ TL;DR - ‚úÖ Stopping the full format at 18% is **safe** - üßπ Just reformat afterward using your preferred tool - üö´ Don‚Äôt power off the drive while it‚Äôs mid-write (you‚Äôre fine if you just Ctrl+C) Let me know if you want a quick format or test-ready prep next ‚Äî happy to guide!

User: I just unlinked OneDrive and deleted the OneDrive folder in my user name. All of the files are safely on the cloud. I want to clean uo my registry but I don't presenltly have a third party app. Can you recommend a registry cleaner?

System:

Assistant: Great move keeping your OneDrive files safe in the cloud before cleaning up. Regarding **registry cleaners**, here are a few well-known and generally safe options: --- ### üßº Popular & Trusted Registry Cleaners #### üîπ **CCleaner (Free & Pro versions)** - One of the most popular tools - Registry cleaner is cautious and gives you a backup option - Also includes junk file cleanup, startup manager, etc. - [Website](https://www.ccleaner.com/) #### üîπ **Wise Registry Cleaner** - Free, lightweight, and user-friendly - Offers ‚ÄúSafe,‚Äù ‚ÄúDeep,‚Äù and ‚ÄúCustom‚Äù scan modes - Registry defrag option included - [Website](https://www.wisecleaner.com/wise-registry-cleaner.html) #### üîπ **Auslogics Registry Cleaner** - Free version with optional Pro upgrade - Good for general cleanup and known for its conservative approach (won‚Äôt aggressively remove entries) - [Website](https://www.auslogics.com/en/software/registry-cleaner/) --- ### ‚ö†Ô∏è A Few Cautions - Always **back up your registry** before making any changes (most tools above offer this automatically). - Registry cleaning is **not usually needed for performance** on modern systems, but can help resolve lingering uninstall traces and OneDrive entries in your case. - Avoid obscure or overly aggressive cleaners ‚Äî they may cause more harm than good. --- Would you like help with manual registry steps (e.g., checking leftover OneDrive entries), or are you looking for a quick "one-button" cleanup with one of these tools?

System:

User: After troubleshooting my hard drive issues above and removing all of my OneDrive files, Unlinking the PC from OneDrive and additionally adding Norton 360 to the computer snf running scans, I am now able to move large files between frive on my system. I need to have a properly functioning OneDrive account on this device, But I am looking for suggestions on how to avoid future conflicts with OneDrive on My Windows 1 PC.

System:

Assistant: That‚Äôs a huge win ‚Äî great job working through everything methodically! üéâ You've cleared several major obstacles, and now you're ready to bring OneDrive back **the *right* way** to avoid future slowdowns, file copy issues, or weird disk behavior. Let‚Äôs walk through **how to set up OneDrive cleanly** and **avoid conflicts** going forward: --- ## üßº Step 1: Prep for a Clean OneDrive Reinstall 1. **Ensure OneDrive is fully removed**: - Open `Settings ‚Üí Apps ‚Üí Installed Apps` - Search for **OneDrive** - If it‚Äôs still listed, uninstall it - Also check your `%UserProfile%` for leftover `OneDrive` folders ‚Äî delete if empty 2. **Clear residual registry entries (optional but clean)**: - Use one of the registry tools we discussed (e.g., **CCleaner** or **Wise Registry Cleaner**) to sweep out any leftover traces --- ## üîÅ Step 2: Reinstall OneDrive Cleanly 1. Download the latest OneDrive installer: üîó https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/onedrive/download 2. Install and sign in **only when ready** to sync. 3. **Choose ‚ÄúThis device only‚Äù at first** (avoid automatically syncing entire cloud to local disk). --- ## ‚öôÔ∏è Step 3: Configure for Stability and Performance ### ‚úÖ **Key Settings to Change During/After Setup** 1. **Files On-Demand** - Keep enabled! (It reduces disk usage and helps avoid space conflicts) - Settings ‚Üí ‚ÄúSave space and download files as you use them‚Äù ‚úîÔ∏è 2. **Selective Sync** - During setup, **only sync the folders you actually need locally** - This avoids syncing huge folders to a drive with limited space 3. **Disable automatic Photos, Screenshots, and Desktop sync** - These can clutter OneDrive with tons of files (especially if you're active in your shop) - Settings ‚Üí Backup ‚Üí Manage Backup ‚Üí Uncheck unnecessary folders 4. **Set OneDrive to start with Windows**, but only **after system boot is stable** - Use Task Manager ‚Üí Startup tab ‚Üí Delay OneDrive if needed --- ## üß† Pro Tips to Avoid Conflicts ### 1. **Avoid Dragging Huge Local Folders *into* OneDrive** - Instead, **copy small chunks or use "Move to OneDrive" context menu** - Upload limits or background syncing can bottleneck the system ### 2. **Don‚Äôt Backup Entire `Documents` or `Pictures` Folders Automatically** - Especially if these contain app data, CAD files, or shop backups ‚Äî OneDrive can conflict with file locks or permissions ### 3. **Exclude OneDrive from Security Software Overreach** - Now that you're running **Norton 360**, go into Norton and **whitelist** OneDrive's process (`OneDrive.exe`) to avoid unnecessary scanning or interference ### 4. **Monitor OneDrive‚Äôs Activity During Big Changes** - Right-click OneDrive icon in taskbar ‚Üí **View sync problems** - Keeps you informed if anything gets stuck or fails silently --- ## üîí Optional: Use a Second Local Backup (Highly Recommended) Even if OneDrive is working perfectly: - Keep a second copy of your key files on a local or external drive - OneDrive sync errors or deletions can propagate to the cloud --- ## ‚úÖ Summary: Clean, Conflict-Free OneDrive Setup | Action | Purpose | |-------------------------------|----------------------------------| | Uninstall + wipe leftover data | Prevent legacy bugs | | Reinstall latest OneDrive | Fresh, stable version | | Files On-Demand + Selective Sync | Saves space, avoids full sync hell | | Delay startup if needed | Prevents boot slowdowns | | Avoid auto folder backup | Reduces clutter and app conflict | | Add Norton exceptions | Avoids false positives or blocks | --- Let me know if you‚Äôd like a **script or checklist** to automate some of this ‚Äî or if you‚Äôd like help crafting a rock-solid backup strategy around OneDrive and your local drives.

User: I did a clean install of OneDrive and now I have two "John - Personal" see screenshot. I ave only one OneDrive folder in C:\Users\jmike. I just created and saved a Word document "Driver update 3-30-2025 and saved it in word to John Long's OneDrive >ChatGPT. The new file does not appear in either "John - Personal" folder > chatGPT or in the OneDrive folder in my user directory. Using Treesize to search for the file, the only thing present was an appdata reference see screenshot. Checking OneDrive on the web, the file was uploaded and present. Can you analyze for me?

Assistant: You're doing an excellent job monitoring your system, and this is a great observation ‚Äî the **discrepancy between what Word saved, what OneDrive displays, and what appears locally** definitely needs clarification. Let's break this down based on your screenshots and your summary. --- ## üß† Key Observations 1. **Two ‚ÄúJohn - Personal‚Äù OneDrive entries appear in File Explorer's sidebar** ‚úÖ This usually means **you have two OneDrive accounts connected** ‚Äî often the same email, but **two profile entries** (e.g., cached from a prior session, or a new reinstallation that wasn't fully cleaned up). 2. **Your Word document ("Driver update 3-30-2025") was saved and synced to OneDrive on the web**, but... - ‚ùå It does **not appear in either of the visible ‚ÄúJohn - Personal‚Äù folders in Explorer** - ‚úÖ Treesize only found a **shortcut (`.url`)** in `AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Office\Recent` ‚Äî this confirms **Word accessed/saved the file**, but you don't have a local copy. 3. You confirmed that there's only **one OneDrive folder** in `C:\Users\jmike\OneDrive` --- ## üìå Root Cause (Most Likely) Your **Word document was saved to a OneDrive location that is not locally synced** ‚Äî probably due to: - OneDrive‚Äôs **Files On-Demand** feature (cloud-only file) - Or, more likely in this case: - **Multiple OneDrive account profiles**, where Word saved to a cloud-only folder from one profile, and File Explorer is showing another It looks like: - Word is pointed to one instance of OneDrive - File Explorer is showing a different one - You may have a ‚Äúghost‚Äù or leftover OneDrive profile entry that‚Äôs causing confusion --- ## ‚úÖ What You Can Do to Resolve This ### üîç Step 1: Check What Account Word Is Using 1. Open **Word** 2. Go to **File > Account** 3. Look under **Connected Services** ‚Üí See what OneDrive accounts are listed 4. Check if it's saving to a path like: `OneDrive - John Long > Chat Gpt` Compare that with what **Explorer** shows under your OneDrive folder. --- ### üßº Step 2: Clean Up Duplicate OneDrive Accounts in File Explorer You can remove OneDrive ‚Äúghost‚Äù entries: 1. Right-click one of the `John - Personal` entries in File Explorer 2. Choose **Settings** 3. In the OneDrive settings window, go to the **Account** tab 4. See if **two accounts** are listed - If yes, remove the redundant one 5. Restart File Explorer (or reboot) You should now see **only one OneDrive** in File Explorer. --- ### üõ†Ô∏è Step 3: Ensure Files Are Actually Downloaded Locally - Right-click the folder where you expect files (like `Chat Gpt`) - Choose **‚ÄúAlways keep on this device‚Äù** - This ensures all files are physically available, not just cloud-only placeholders --- ### üß™ Bonus: Double-Check Where Word is Actually Saving To verify file path: 1. Open Word 2. Create a test doc 3. Save As ‚Üí Browse ‚Üí right-click in the path bar 4. Choose ‚ÄúCopy address‚Äù 5. Paste into Notepad to see **exact save path** You‚Äôll likely see a difference between: ``` C:\Users\jmike\OneDrive\Chat Gpt ``` vs. ``` C:\Users\jmike\OneDrive - John Long\Chat Gpt ``` That would confirm the account mismatch. --- ## ‚úÖ TL;DR: What‚Äôs Happening | Observation | Explanation | |--------------------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------| | File saved in Word, but not visible | Saved to cloud-only OneDrive profile not synced locally | | Two "John - Personal" entries | Multiple OneDrive profiles cached in Explorer | | File appears on web but not locally | File is in cloud-only folder from secondary account | | Shortcut in AppData only | Word made a shortcut to the remote cloud file | --- Let me know what Word says under its Account settings ‚Äî that‚Äôll help confirm which OneDrive it‚Äôs pointing to. I can also help you remove any lingering profile entries to get things fully synced and clean.

User: I may see the problem. I have my laptop linked to this same account so that my files stay updated on both computers. Will unlinking the account on the laptop temporarily clera this up?

Assistant: üí° **Yes ‚Äî unlinking the account on your laptop temporarily is a smart troubleshooting step**, especially since: - You‚Äôre seeing **multiple ‚ÄúJohn - Personal‚Äù entries** in File Explorer - Word is saving files to OneDrive (which end up **only in the cloud**, not locally synced) - The **confusion likely stems from OneDrive syncing the same account to two devices**, and possibly syncing different folders or having split profiles due to earlier installs/uninstalls --- ### ‚úÖ What Unlinking the Laptop Will Do - **Stops the OneDrive sync** on the laptop (without deleting cloud files) - Will not remove any existing local files on the laptop - **May eliminate a duplicate profile entry** from your desktop‚Äôs File Explorer - Prevents additional file updates while you get your desktop OneDrive back under control You can always re-link it later after confirming the desktop works as expected. --- ### üõ†Ô∏è Steps to Temporarily Unlink the Laptop 1. On the **laptop**, click the OneDrive cloud icon in the taskbar 2. Click the **gear icon (Settings)** ‚Üí **Settings** 3. Go to the **Account** tab 4. Click **Unlink this PC** 5. Confirm the prompt This will: - Stop syncing to that OneDrive account - Leave files already downloaded on the laptop intact - Free your desktop OneDrive from possible identity/profile confusion --- ### ‚úÖ Then on Your Desktop After unlinking the laptop: 1. Reboot your desktop (just to clear session data) 2. Check **File Explorer** ‚Äî confirm that you're now seeing **only one ‚ÄúJohn - Personal‚Äù** 3. Create a test file in Word ‚Üí Save to OneDrive ‚Üí Confirm it appears **locally** 4. Make sure ‚ÄúFiles On-Demand‚Äù is **enabled**, and ‚ÄúChat Gpt‚Äù is set to **always keep on this device** (so you avoid ghost/cloud-only files) --- ### üí° After It‚Äôs Stable‚Ä¶ Once your desktop‚Äôs OneDrive is: - Syncing correctly - Showing files locally - Not duplicating profile entries Then you can re-link your laptop again. --- Let me know when you‚Äôve unlinked the laptop and I‚Äôll walk you through a clean check/reset on the desktop. You‚Äôre almost there!

User: II unlinked. The laptop. From Onedrive. I restarted the computer. And verified that I had the new file in both of the John personals. I would like to safely remove one of the John's personal. account on the File Explorer window.

Assistant: Perfect ‚Äî you‚Äôve done all the right things, and now you‚Äôre in the home stretch! üéØ Since the file is now visible in **both ‚ÄúJohn - Personal‚Äù entries**, it confirms they‚Äôre likely **redundant pointers to the same cloud account**, probably from past installs or sync states. Let‚Äôs now **safely remove the duplicate OneDrive entry** from File Explorer. --- ## üßº Step-by-Step: Remove Duplicate ‚ÄúJohn - Personal‚Äù Entry ### ‚úÖ Step 1: Check Active OneDrive Account(s) 1. Click the **OneDrive cloud icon** in your **taskbar** 2. Click the **gear icon (‚öô)** ‚Üí **Settings** 3. Go to the **Account** tab You should now see **only one OneDrive account** linked (John - Personal). If more than one appears, click **‚ÄúUnlink this PC‚Äù** on the one you want to remove. --- ### ‚úÖ Step 2: Remove the Extra OneDrive Folder from File Explorer If only **one account** is listed under OneDrive settings but **two still appear** in File Explorer, you‚Äôre dealing with a **leftover registry entry**. Here‚Äôs how to clean that up: --- ### üõ†Ô∏è Option 1: Use Registry Editor (Manual Clean) > ‚ö†Ô∏è Backup your registry first! This is safe if followed carefully. 1. Press `Win + R` ‚Üí type `regedit` ‚Üí Enter 2. Navigate to: ``` HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Desktop\NameSpace ``` 3. Inside `NameSpace`, you‚Äôll see several folders with long `{GUID}` names. 4. One or more of these are linked to OneDrive‚Äôs "John - Personal" entries üß™ To identify the right one: - Click on each `{GUID}` folder - In the **right pane**, look for a value like `Name` or `Default` that says `OneDrive - John - Personal` 5. Once you find the **duplicate**, right-click that `{GUID}` key ‚Üí **Delete** --- ### üîÅ Option 2: Rebuild the Explorer Sidebar Automatically If you're not comfortable editing the registry manually, here‚Äôs the safer route: 1. Sign out of OneDrive again (if needed) 2. Run the following from **PowerShell** (as Admin): ```powershell Stop-Process -Name explorer -Force Start-Process explorer ``` Then: 3. Open PowerShell and run: ```powershell Get-ChildItem -Path "HKCU:\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Desktop\NameSpace" | ForEach-Object { Get-ItemProperty $_.PSPath } | Where-Object { $_."(Default)" -like "*OneDrive*" } ``` That will **list the OneDrive registry keys**, so you can confirm which are linked to "John - Personal" ‚Äî and then choose whether to delete one using `regedit`. --- ## ‚úÖ Optional: Fully Reset OneDrive If the duplicates persist and you want a hard reset: 1. Unlink OneDrive again 2. Open `Run` (Win + R) and type: ```cmd %localappdata%\Microsoft\OneDrive\onedrive.exe /reset ``` Wait 1‚Äì2 minutes. Then run: ```cmd %localappdata%\Microsoft\OneDrive\onedrive.exe ``` This will **reset the OneDrive sync engine**, and usually removes phantom File Explorer entries. --- ## üß≠ Final Advice Once you‚Äôre down to one clean entry: - Confirm your Chat Gpt folder syncs locally and shows a green checkmark or cloud icon - Re-link your laptop if you wish - You‚Äôll have a stable, clean OneDrive setup again üòé Let me know if you'd like help deleting that specific registry entry ‚Äî I can walk you through using the PowerShell output to pinpoint the duplicate.

User: %localappdata%\Microsoft\OneDrive\onedrive.exe /reset 'C:\Users\jmike\AppData\Local\Microsoft\OneDrive\onedrive.exe' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file.

Assistant: Ah, good catch ‚Äî that's a common Windows quirk. When running a path like that with spaces in it **and including a command-line argument**, you need to **wrap the full path in quotes**, not just the path portion. --- ## ‚úÖ Correct Command Format Open a **Command Prompt** (or press `Win + R`) and run this **exact line**: ```cmd "%localappdata%\Microsoft\OneDrive\onedrive.exe" /reset ``` > ‚úÖ The quotes wrap the **entire path to the executable**, and `/reset` is outside the quotes. This will: - Reset OneDrive - Stop syncing temporarily - Clear cache and settings (but not your files or linked cloud data) --- ### üïê What to Expect After Running - The OneDrive cloud icon in the system tray will **disappear briefly** - After 1‚Äì2 minutes, it may automatically restart - If it doesn‚Äôt restart, run: ```cmd "%localappdata%\Microsoft\OneDrive\onedrive.exe" ``` That will relaunch the OneDrive client and re-initiate the setup. --- Let me know if you'd like help confirming the reset worked or checking if the duplicate "John - Personal" is gone. You're *so close* to a squeaky clean setup!

User: still the same response

Assistant: Thanks for sticking with it ‚Äî if you're getting: ``` 'C:\Users\jmike\AppData\Local\Microsoft\OneDrive\onedrive.exe' is not recognized... ``` ...even **with quotes**, then it's likely that the OneDrive executable is either: 1. **Not installed in that folder** (e.g., it might be in `Program Files`) 2. **Not installed at all** (which seems unlikely since OneDrive is working) 3. **Blocked or moved** due to the reset, antivirus, or previous cleanup --- ## ‚úÖ Let's Locate the Real OneDrive Executable ### üìç Step 1: Search for `onedrive.exe` Open **File Explorer** and in the **search bar**, type: ``` onedrive.exe ``` Wait a moment ‚Äî you‚Äôre looking for one of these **likely paths**: - `C:\Users\jmike\AppData\Local\Microsoft\OneDrive\onedrive.exe` ‚úÖ (the default per-user install) - `C:\Program Files\Microsoft OneDrive\onedrive.exe` - `C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft OneDrive\onedrive.exe` Note the **full path** to the one that‚Äôs active and most recently modified. --- ### üìç Step 2: Run the Reset From That Path Once you know the real path (e.g., `C:\Program Files\Microsoft OneDrive\onedrive.exe`), open **Command Prompt** and run: ```cmd "" /reset ``` Example: ```cmd "C:\Program Files\Microsoft OneDrive\onedrive.exe" /reset ``` --- ### üß† If You‚Äôre Unsure Which is Active Open **Task Manager**, go to the **Details tab**, and find `OneDrive.exe` ‚Üí Right-click ‚Üí **Open file location** Then use that location in your command. --- Let me know what path it‚Äôs in ‚Äî or feel free to paste the one you find, and I‚Äôll give you the exact command to copy/paste.

User: 'onedrive.exe' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file.

Assistant: Thanks for hanging in there ‚Äî you're being super thorough, and we're nearly there. That message confirms that Windows **cannot find `onedrive.exe` in the system path**, and likely not even in its expected install locations. Let‚Äôs fix this by **manually finding and running** OneDrive properly. --- ## ‚úÖ Step-by-Step Recovery: Locate and Reset OneDrive ### üß≠ 1. Find Where OneDrive is Installed #### Method A ‚Äì Use File Explorer Search 1. Open **File Explorer** 2. In the **This PC** view, type: ``` onedrive.exe ``` 3. Wait for it to search. You're looking for a path like: - `C:\Users\jmike\AppData\Local\Microsoft\OneDrive\onedrive.exe` - or `C:\Program Files\Microsoft OneDrive\onedrive.exe` Note the **full path**. --- #### Method B ‚Äì Use Task Manager (if OneDrive is running) 1. Press `Ctrl + Shift + Esc` to open **Task Manager** 2. Click the **Details** tab 3. Find `OneDrive.exe` in the list 4. Right-click ‚Üí **Open file location** Copy the full path from the address bar. --- ### üõ† 2. Run Reset Command with Correct Path Assume you found it at this example path: ``` C:\Program Files\Microsoft OneDrive\OneDrive.exe ``` Then in **Command Prompt**, type: ```cmd "C:\Program Files\Microsoft OneDrive\OneDrive.exe" /reset ``` Make sure: - You use quotes if the path contains spaces - You include the `/reset` **outside** the quotes --- ### üí° If That Still Fails... If `OneDrive.exe` **doesn‚Äôt exist anywhere**, it may have been: - Accidentally removed - Corrupted - Blocked by antivirus #### ‚úÖ Reinstall It Manually 1. Download the official OneDrive installer: üîó [https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=844652](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=844652) 2. Run the installer 3. Once installed, try the reset again (or just reconfigure it from scratch) --- Let me know what the search turns up ‚Äî if you paste the path here, I‚Äôll give you the exact reset command line. You're nearly back to a pristine OneDrive state.

User: I reset OneDrive Successfully. 2 John Personal links remain at the top of file explorer. See attached. I only have 1 Onedrive directory in my user account, see attached. My thoughts are to unlink this PC from OneDrive and then re-link it to see if that clears up the problem. What do you think?

Assistant: Your instincts are üî• spot-on. The screenshots confirm: - ‚úÖ Only **one actual OneDrive folder** in `C:\Users\jmike\OneDrive` - ‚ùå Yet **two ‚ÄúJohn - Personal‚Äù entries** still linger in File Explorer‚Äôs sidebar - ‚úÖ OneDrive reset worked correctly So yes ‚Äî **unlinking and re-linking OneDrive** is a great next move, especially now that everything‚Äôs stable and you‚Äôve confirmed where your actual files live. --- ## ‚úÖ Plan: Clean Re-Link to Remove Sidebar Duplicates ### üîÅ Step 1: Unlink OneDrive Again 1. Click the **OneDrive cloud icon** in your system tray 2. Click the **gear icon (‚öô)** ‚Üí **Settings** 3. Go to the **Account** tab 4. Click **Unlink this PC** --- ### üßπ Step 2: Clear OneDrive Registry Entries (Optional, but Helps) If you want to remove the ghost sidebar entries before re-linking: 1. Press `Win + R` ‚Üí type `regedit` ‚Üí Enter 2. Go to: ``` HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Desktop\NameSpace ``` 3. Look through the `{GUID}` entries in the left pane 4. Click each one and check the right pane for anything that says: ``` OneDrive - John - Personal ``` 5. If you find **two entries for "John - Personal"**, delete one of them (right-click ‚Üí Delete) *Optional*: Repeat the check here: ``` HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\ ``` Search for the same `OneDrive` string ‚Äî those sometimes control File Explorer's sidebar appearance too. --- ### üîÅ Step 3: Re-Link OneDrive Cleanly 1. Run: ```cmd "%localappdata%\Microsoft\OneDrive\OneDrive.exe" ``` 2. Sign in to OneDrive 3. Choose your folder locations carefully ‚Äî use the **default (`C:\Users\jmike\OneDrive`)** 4. Avoid syncing unnecessary folders (e.g., Desktop, Pictures) to prevent clutter 5. **Don‚Äôt rename anything** during setup --- ### ‚úÖ Step 4: Reboot After re-linking: - Restart your PC - You should now see only **one ‚ÄúJohn - Personal‚Äù** entry - If not, the registry cleanup will ensure the extra one disappears over the next reboot or Explorer refresh --- ## üß≠ Final Thoughts This is a classic leftover registry ghost from prior installs/unlinks ‚Äî not harmful, just annoying. Your system looks super clean overall now, and this will lock it down. Let me know if you want a quick `.reg` file to automatically delete the duplicate sidebar entry, or if you want to review the registry entries together before deleting.

User: Checking HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\ I find no entry?

Assistant: Great ‚Äî that actually simplifies things. If **no OneDrive entries are found in `HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\CLSID\`**, then the duplicate **sidebar entries are most likely living under**: ``` HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Desktop\NameSpace ``` That‚Äôs the **primary place File Explorer gets its custom "Quick Access" or sidebar links**. --- ## ‚úÖ Here‚Äôs How to Safely Find and Remove the Duplicate ### üîç Step 1: Go to the Correct Registry Key 1. Press `Win + R`, type: `regedit`, press **Enter** 2. Navigate to: ``` HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Explorer\Desktop\NameSpace ``` --- ### üîé Step 2: Identify OneDrive Sidebar Entries Under the `NameSpace` key, you'll see folders named like `{018D5C66-4533-4307-9B53-224DE2ED1FE6}` ‚Äî those are sidebar items. Click each one. In the **right-hand pane**, look at the **(Default)** value: - You're looking for something like: ``` OneDrive - John - Personal ``` You‚Äôll likely find **two** that say this. That‚Äôs your duplicate. --- ### üßΩ Step 3: Remove One of the Duplicates Once confirmed: - Right-click **just one of them** - Click **Delete** - Confirm the deletion ‚ö†Ô∏è **Be careful not to delete unrelated entries** ‚Äî only the one where the (Default) value clearly mentions OneDrive or ‚ÄúJohn - Personal‚Äù. --- ### üîÅ Step 4: Restart File Explorer 1. Press `Ctrl + Shift + Esc` to open **Task Manager** 2. Find **Windows Explorer** in the list 3. Right-click ‚Üí **Restart** You can also log out and back in or reboot the system. --- ### ‚úÖ After That - Open File Explorer again - You should now see only **one "John - Personal"** in the sidebar - OneDrive will still function fully, syncing from your known-good `C:\Users\jmike\OneDrive` folder --- Let me know what you find under the `NameSpace` key ‚Äî if you're unsure about which entry to delete, you can export the registry keys and I‚Äôll help you identify the correct one.

User: Wonderful advice! I am up and running! only 1 John's Personal link in the file explorer sidebar.

Assistant: üéâ **YES! That‚Äôs the win we were chasing!** You just untangled a *seriously tricky* OneDrive + Windows Sidebar + registry ghost mess ‚Äî and you did it like a pro. Your system is now: - ‚úÖ Cleanly linked to **OneDrive** - ‚úÖ Free of redundant sidebar clutter - ‚úÖ Syncing correctly without confusion - ‚úÖ Backed by your own careful verification (love the TreeSize and registry checks!) --- If you want, I can help you: - Automate future backups of your OneDrive folders - Set up cloud folder versioning or redundancy with Google Drive or local drives - Or export a clean `.reg` backup now that things are fixed But for now‚Ä¶ enjoy the sweet, quiet hum of a system that‚Äôs finally playing nice. üòÑ Let me know if you want to bookmark this recovery setup somewhere ‚Äî happy to drop it in a Notion template or Word doc for future reference.

User: Now that you mention it, I initially attempted to back up my OneDrive data to Google drive, since I now have an account that will hold 2TB of datathere. Initially, I succeded in uploading several GB of data but then, Google Drive started sending errors on my drag and drop requests. Is there a better way to backup my OneDrive Data to Google Drive for redundancy?

Assistant: Ah yes ‚Äî **Google Drive is fantastic for 2TB redundancy**, but drag-and-drop via browser is definitely **not the best method** for large-scale or ongoing syncs. You‚Äôre not alone ‚Äî lots of people run into errors with: - Large file batches - Nested folders - Network interruptions - Sync conflicts --- ## ‚úÖ Best Ways to Back Up OneDrive Data to Google Drive Here are **3 solid methods**, from easiest to most automated: --- ### üîπ **Option 1: Use Google Drive for Desktop (Recommended)** Google‚Äôs official sync app lets you **treat Google Drive like a regular folder**, and it‚Äôs *way more reliable* than dragging into the browser. #### ‚úÖ Steps: 1. Download Google Drive for Desktop: üîó https://www.google.com/drive/download/ 2. During setup: - Choose **Mirror or Stream** mode (Mirror = local copy, Stream = on-demand) - Let it mount as a drive (e.g., `G:`) 3. Now copy from: ``` C:\Users\jmike\OneDrive\ ‚Üí G:\My Drive\OneDrive Backup\ ``` 4. Use File Explorer or robocopy (see Option 3) for smooth transfer #### ‚úÖ Pros: - Easy drag-and-drop with **auto-resume** - Works with folder structures and large files - Supports real-time sync if you leave the folder linked #### ‚ö†Ô∏è Watch for: - File name compatibility (Google Drive doesn‚Äôt like `*`, `?`, etc.) - Google rate limits if you push too fast --- ### üîπ **Option 2: Use a Cloud-to-Cloud Backup Tool** If you want **automated backup between clouds** (no local copy), try a service like: - üîÑ **MultCloud** (https://www.multcloud.com/) - ‚òÅÔ∏è **CloudHQ** (https://www.cloudhq.net/) - üóÇÔ∏è **Rclone** (if you‚Äôre technical) #### How It Works: - Log in with OneDrive + Google Drive - Set up a **scheduled sync job** - It transfers files **cloud-to-cloud** ‚Äî fast and hands-off #### Pros: - No bandwidth used on your PC - Fully automated - Can be scheduled or real-time #### Cons: - Free tiers may have limits - Premium plans range $10‚Äì$15/month --- ### üîπ **Option 3: Use Robocopy (For Power Users)** Use `robocopy` for smart, resumable, bulk copy with log support. ```cmd robocopy "C:\Users\jmike\OneDrive" "G:\My Drive\OneDrive Backup" /E /Z /MT:8 /R:3 /W:5 /LOG:C:\backup_log.txt ``` - `/E` ‚Äì copy all subfolders - `/Z` ‚Äì resume mode (crash-safe) - `/MT:8` ‚Äì multithreaded (adjust # for speed) - `/LOG:` ‚Äì saves output for review üöÄ Super reliable for large backups. --- ## üîê Bonus: Prevent Sync Errors - ‚úÖ Clean up OneDrive file names (avoid `| < > : ? *`) - ‚úÖ Avoid path lengths over **255 characters** - ‚úÖ Keep uploads under Google‚Äôs **750 GB/day** per user limit (if you upload a lot) --- ## üß≠ TL;DR: Best Method? | Method | Best For | Notes | |------------------------|--------------------------------------|----------------------------------------| | Google Drive for Desktop | Simple, local file-based syncing | Great for Explorer/robocopy workflows | | MultCloud / CloudHQ | Cloud-to-cloud backup (no download) | Best if you want automation | | Robocopy | Fast manual syncs or scripting | Great for recurring backups or logging | --- Let me know your vibe ‚Äî want a step-by-step on using `robocopy` or setting up a tool like MultCloud? I can get you dialed in based on how hands-off or scripted you want this.

User: Previously, When Google Drive offered 15GB of free storage, I set up Google Drive Desktop as a drive on my device. See attached screenshot. How can i modify this drive to perfom Mirror or Stream mode (Mirror = local copy, Stream = on-demand)

Assistant: Thanks for the screenshot ‚Äî it shows that **Google Drive is mounted as `G:`**, which means you're already using **Google Drive for Desktop** üëç. Now you‚Äôre just looking to **switch between Stream and Mirror modes**. Here‚Äôs how to do it: --- ## üîÑ Switch Between Mirror and Stream Modes in Google Drive for Desktop ### ‚úÖ Step 1: Open Google Drive Preferences 1. Click the **Google Drive icon** in your system tray (lower-right corner of your screen) - You may need to click the ‚ÄúShow hidden icons‚Äù (`^`) if you don‚Äôt see it 2. Click the **gear icon** (‚öôÔ∏è) in the top-right of the Google Drive window 3. Choose **Preferences** --- ### ‚öôÔ∏è Step 2: Select Syncing Mode Once in Preferences: 1. Under **"My Drive syncing options"**, you‚Äôll see: - üîò **Stream files** (Files are online-only unless opened or marked to be kept locally) - üîò **Mirror files** (Files are **always downloaded** and kept in sync) 2. Choose the option you want: - If you want **space-saving on-demand access**, choose **Stream** - If you want a **local backup** copy of everything on Google Drive, choose **Mirror** --- ### üìÇ Step 3: Confirm/Change Folder Location (Optional) If switching to **Mirror mode**, it will prompt you to choose a **local folder location** for the mirrored copy. > üìù Tip: You can set this to `C:\Users\jmike\GoogleDrive` or something like `D:\GDriveMirror` if you want to store it on a different drive. --- ### üîÑ Step 4: Google Drive Will Restart and Re-Sync After applying the new sync mode: - Google Drive may **restart** automatically - It will begin **downloading or cleaning up** based on the selected mode - You‚Äôll still access it through `G:` or from File Explorer sidebar --- ## ‚úÖ Verify the Change To confirm you‚Äôre in the correct mode: - Hover over the Google Drive icon in the taskbar - It will say something like: - ‚ÄúMy Drive: Streaming from cloud‚Äù (for Stream) - ‚ÄúMy Drive: Mirroring locally‚Äù (for Mirror) --- ## üí° Extra Tips - Want specific folders available offline in **Stream mode**? ‚Üí Right-click a file or folder ‚Üí **Available offline** - Want to switch back later? Just repeat the process in Preferences --- Let me know which mode you want to use, and I can walk you through optimizing it for backup or file redundancy.

User: I think that I have it! I had to add Johgn Personal to the stream sync an it is uploading.

Assistant: üëè That‚Äôs *awesome* ‚Äî sounds like you nailed it! By adding **"John - Personal" (your OneDrive folder)** to Google Drive's **Stream sync**, you‚Äôre now backing up your OneDrive data directly to Google Drive ‚Äî with: - ‚úÖ **Real-time upload** - ‚úÖ **Cloud redundancy** - ‚úÖ No drag-and-drop errors - ‚úÖ No wasted local space if you stay in Stream mode --- ### üß† Bonus Tip: Monitor Sync Activity You can always keep an eye on upload progress by: - Clicking the **Google Drive icon** in the system tray - Watching the status text (e.g., ‚ÄúUploading 153 files‚Ä¶‚Äù) - Clicking the gear ‚Üí **Preferences** ‚Üí ‚ÄúActivity‚Äù tab --- ### üì¶ Optional: Organize Your Backup Folder If you want clean separation, you could have Google Drive back up to: ``` G:\My Drive\Backups\OneDrive-John ``` To do that: - In Preferences ‚Üí **Add folder** ‚Üí Select `C:\Users\jmike\OneDrive` - Choose destination: `Backups\OneDrive-John` on Google Drive --- You're officially running a **multi-cloud, real-time backup system** now. üòé Let me know if you want to automate periodic snapshots or version history tricks ‚Äî or just enjoy the peace of mind!
