255.255.255.0 Lease Obtained. . . . . . . . . . : Wednesday, March 26, 2025 7:21:31 AM Lease Expires . . . . . . . . . . : Wednesday, March 26, 2025 11:21:29 AM Default Gateway . . . . . . . . . : fe80::208:a2ff:fe0f:a687%18 10.69.0.1 DHCP Server . . . . . . . . . . . : 10.69.0.1 DHCPv6 IAID . . . . . . . . . . . : 174120334 DHCPv6 Client DUID. . . . . . . . : 00-01-00-01-2B-D0-72-66-D8-BB-C1-A3-81-06 DNS Servers . . . . . . . . . . . : 10.69.0.1 NetBIOS over Tcpip. . . . . . . . : Enabled Connection-specific DNS Suffix Search List : marmaduke.local Ethernet adapter Bluetooth Network Connection: Media State . . . . . . . . . . . : Media disconnected Connection-specific DNS Suffix . : Description . . . . . . . . . . . : Bluetooth Device (Personal Area Network) Physical Address. . . . . . . . . : 60-DD-8E-F6-F3-41 DHCP Enabled. . . . . . . . . . . : Yes Autoconfiguration Enabled . . . . : Yes PS C:\Users\jmike>

Assistant: Ah, thanks for the clarification ‚Äî that makes *much* more sense now. Based on the `ipconfig /all` output, you've got a solid setup, and the `marmaduke.local` part is just your internal DNS suffix, which is fine and expected. So, to summarize: - ‚úÖ **Proton VPN is functioning** - ‚úÖ You're on VLAN 4 with a static IP (`10.69.0.100`) - ‚úÖ DNS server shown is `10.69.0.1` (pfSense) - ‚ùå **Your real ISP IP is still showing up on ipleak.net**, alongside your VPN IP Let‚Äôs zero in on the actual issue: --- ## üß† What‚Äôs Likely Happening You're seeing both your **ISP (WAN) IP** *and* **VPN tunnel IP** because: 1. **pfSense (10.69.0.1) is the DNS server**, and it's **forwarding requests out the WAN**, not through the VPN tunnel. 2. That means your DNS queries **exit unencrypted** through your regular ISP. 3. Also possible: **Split routing**, where certain requests (like DNS or WebRTC) are still using the default route (WAN). --- ## ‚úÖ Fix: Lock DNS Requests to VPN ### Step 1: Force pfSense DNS Resolver to Use VPN Tunnel 1. Go to `Services > DNS Resolver` 2. Under **Outgoing Network Interfaces**, change from `All` to just the **VPN interface (e.g., `ovpnc1`)** 3. Save & Apply This ensures pfSense sends **all DNS lookups through Proton VPN**, *not* WAN. --- ### Step 2: Firewall Rule ‚Äì Prevent DNS via WAN Go to `Firewall > Rules > VLAN 4` (or whatever interface your desktop is on): 1. Add a **block rule at the top**: - **Action**: Block - **Protocol**: TCP/UDP - **Source**: `10.69.0.100` - **Destination**: `any` - **Destination Port**: 53 - **Gateway**: `WAN` This prevents your desktop from ever resolving DNS over the WAN gateway. 2. Add an **allow rule directly after**: - **Action**: Pass - **Source**: `10.69.0.100` - **Destination**: `Proton DNS (162.252.172.57)` - **Port**: 53 - **Gateway**: `VPN gateway (e.g., Proton_VPN_GW)` 3. Ensure default pass rules for VLAN 4 use the **VPN gateway**, not default (auto) --- ### Step 3: Optionally Set Proton DNS Directly on the Client Since you‚Äôre assigning a static IP to `10.69.0.100`, you can **bypass pfSense‚Äôs resolver** by setting the DNS manually: - On Windows: - Go to your Ethernet adapter settings - Under `IPv4` properties, **manually set** DNS to `162.252.172.57` - Remove `10.69.0.1` from the DNS list This ensures your machine talks *only* to Proton DNS, skipping pfSense for DNS. --- ### Step 4: Verify Routing Table in pfSense Go to `Diagnostics > Routes` - Check that **traffic from 10.69.0.100** goes to **the VPN gateway** - If anything is going to WAN, double-check your **Firewall > Rules > VLAN 4** --- ### Step 5: Retest Leak After making these changes: - Flush DNS: ```powershell ipconfig /flushdns ``` - Reboot your browser - Visit: - [ipleak.net](https://ipleak.net) - [browserleaks.com](https://browserleaks.com/ip) - [dnsleaktest.com](https://dnsleaktest.com) ‚úÖ You should now only see: - Proton IP - DNS = Proton DNS (162.252.172.57) - No ISP/WAN IP - No `10.69.0.1` DNS leaks --- Want me to help build exact NAT/firewall rules for your setup in pfSense? Just let me know how your interfaces and aliases are labeled.

User: Since the path of my desktop through the Proton Vpn is only meant to be a temporary one and I will switch back and forth between my LAN and Proton VPN by my switch created by adding or removing my local IP from the list directing it to ProtonVPN tunnel, which option would be best suited for solving my problem?

Assistant: Got it ‚Äî since your Proton VPN routing is **temporary and manually toggled** by editing the alias (i.e., adding/removing `10.69.0.100` from a pfSense alias used in policy-based routing), you'll want a solution that: - ‚úÖ Avoids DNS/IP leaks **while on the VPN** - ‚úÖ Doesn‚Äôt break your regular LAN behavior **when not on the VPN** - ‚úÖ Doesn‚Äôt require reconfiguring your desktop or DNS resolver constantly --- ## üîß Best Solution for Your Use Case ### ‚úÖ Option: Create Conditional Firewall + NAT Rules That Only Apply When on VPN This is the most flexible and least intrusive solution: --- ### 1. **Split Rules Based on Alias (e.g., `ProtonVPN_Clients`)** Let‚Äôs say you use an alias like `ProtonVPN_Clients` to define who goes through the VPN. You can tailor your rules based on that alias. #### In `Firewall > Rules > LAN` or `VLAN 4`: - üîí **Rule #1 (Block DNS over WAN):** - Source: `ProtonVPN_Clients` alias - Destination port: `53` - Protocol: TCP/UDP - **Gateway: WAN** - **Action: Block** - ‚úÖ **Rule #2 (Allow DNS to Proton DNS):** - Source: `ProtonVPN_Clients` - Destination: `162.252.172.57` - Port: `53` - **Gateway: VPN Gateway** - Action: Pass - ‚úÖ **Rule #3 (Default Pass to Any):** - Source: `ProtonVPN_Clients` - Destination: any - Gateway: Proton VPN gateway - Action: Pass - ‚úÖ Other clients: have the usual pass rules to WAN (untouched) --- ### 2. **DNS Resolver ‚Äì Bind to VPN Tunnel** In `Services > DNS Resolver`: - Set **"Outgoing Network Interfaces"** to only `ProtonVPN` interface - That way, even if your desktop is using pfSense as DNS (`10.69.0.1`), the resolver sends queries out the VPN tunnel - Non-VPN clients can still get DNS resolution ‚Äî they'll just route out pfSense, not directly ‚úÖ This helps maintain compatibility while avoiding WAN DNS leaks when you route through VPN. --- ### 3. **No Need to Change Desktop Settings** Since you‚Äôre using DHCP/static IP and the desktop always gets `10.69.0.1` for DNS: - Leave it that way ‚Äî no need to hardcode Proton DNS on the desktop - pfSense will take care of DNS routing *based on whether the desktop is part of the alias or not* --- ### ‚úÖ Summary: Best-Of-Both Worlds | When You're On VPN (Alias Includes IP) | When You're Off VPN (Alias Excludes IP) | |-------------------------------------------|------------------------------------------| | DNS routed through Proton DNS | DNS routed through normal WAN | | Firewall blocks WAN leaks for that IP | Normal access to internet & local DNS | | No browser/IP/DNS leaks via WAN | LAN routing behaves normally | --- If you‚Äôd like, I can help you write those specific pfSense rules using exact names like `VLAN_Proton`, `ProtonVPN_GW`, or your alias ‚Äî just let me know how you've named them.

User: Yes, please. My interfaces are as follows: LAN - Netwok Port = mvneta1 (00:08:a2:0f:a6:87) Used for non VPN traffic Proton_VPN - Network Port = ovpnc1 (Proton_VPN) Used for VPN traffic

Assistant: Perfect ‚Äî thanks for that detail. Based on your setup: - Your desktop (10.69.0.100) is manually added/removed from an alias to switch between: - **LAN** (default gateway ‚Üí WAN) - **Proton_VPN** (gateway ‚Üí VPN) - Interfaces: - **LAN** = `mvneta1` - **Proton_VPN** = `ovpnc1` Let‚Äôs create rules that only affect traffic **when your desktop is routed through the VPN**, using the alias-based method you‚Äôve already got working. --- ## ‚úÖ Setup Overview ### Assumptions: - You have a pfSense **alias**, let‚Äôs say: `ProtonVPN_Clients` ‚Üí contains `10.69.0.100` when VPN is desired - You want to: - Prevent DNS leaks (block WAN DNS when on VPN) - Route DNS to Proton DNS (`162.252.172.57`) - Allow general traffic over VPN when the alias includes the IP - Let everything act normal when the alias excludes the IP --- ## üîß Firewall Rules (on LAN Interface) **Go to**: `Firewall > Rules > LAN` ### üîí Rule 1 ‚Äì Block DNS from VPN clients to WAN - **Action**: Block - **Interface**: LAN - **Protocol**: TCP/UDP - **Source**: `ProtonVPN_Clients` - **Destination Port Range**: 53 - **Destination**: any - **Gateway**: default (leave blank) - **Description**: `Block WAN DNS for VPN clients` This stops DNS leaks through your ISP while on VPN. --- ### ‚úÖ Rule 2 ‚Äì Allow DNS to Proton DNS - **Action**: Pass - **Interface**: LAN - **Protocol**: TCP/UDP - **Source**: `ProtonVPN_Clients` - **Destination**: `162.252.172.57` - **Destination Port Range**: 53 - **Gateway**: `Proton_VPN` (select your VPN gateway here) - **Description**: `Allow DNS to Proton DNS` This sends DNS queries out the tunnel securely. --- ### ‚úÖ Rule 3 ‚Äì Allow all other traffic from VPN clients - **Action**: Pass - **Interface**: LAN - **Protocol**: any - **Source**: `ProtonVPN_Clients` - **Destination**: any - **Gateway**: `Proton_VPN` - **Description**: `VPN client traffic via Proton VPN` This sends all other traffic through the VPN. --- ### ‚úÖ Rule 4 ‚Äì Normal LAN traffic (for everyone else) - **Action**: Pass - **Interface**: LAN - **Source**: any - **Destination**: any - **Gateway**: default (auto) - **Description**: `Default LAN allow` Make sure this rule is **last**, and all VPN rules are **above** it. --- ## üß† DNS Resolver Tweaks (Optional but Recommended) If your desktop is using pfSense (`10.69.0.1`) for DNS, you may also want to bind the resolver to the VPN interface: ### Go to: `Services > DNS Resolver` - Scroll to **Outgoing Network Interfaces** - Select only: `Proton_VPN` (`ovpnc1`) - Save & Apply ‚úÖ This ensures pfSense‚Äôs resolver doesn‚Äôt use WAN for DNS while your VPN clients are active. --- ## üß™ Test it Out Once the rules are saved: 1. **Add your desktop IP to the `ProtonVPN_Clients` alias** 2. Wait ~30 seconds or flush states under `Diagnostics > States` 3. Flush DNS on your desktop: ```powershell ipconfig /flushdns ``` 4. Visit [ipleak.net](https://ipleak.net) or [dnsleaktest.com](https://dnsleaktest.com) You should now only see: - ‚úÖ VPN IP (no ISP IP) - ‚úÖ DNS = Proton (162.252.172.57) - ‚ùå No DNS = 10.69.0.1 or WAN IP Then when you remove the desktop IP from the alias: - The traffic routes normally over LAN/WAN - pfSense no longer forces VPN behavior --- Want help setting up a floating rule or NAT outbound mapping to ensure no fallback occurs? Or are you happy manually managing it all through the alias?

User: In rules 1,2,3 above you refer to: Source:ProtonVPN_Clients.

Assistant: Great question ‚Äî yes! When I refer to: > **Source: `ProtonVPN_Clients`** I‚Äôm referencing a **pfSense alias** that contains IPs (like your desktop: `10.69.0.100`) that you want routed through the Proton VPN. --- ## ‚úÖ If You‚Äôve Already Created the Alias You‚Äôre good to go if you already have something like this under: **Firewall > Aliases > IP** - Name: `ProtonVPN_Clients` *(or similar)* - Type: `Host(s)` - Value: `10.69.0.100` *(and any other IPs you want to VPN route)* That alias becomes usable in **firewall rules** as the source. --- ## ‚ùóÔ∏èIf You Haven‚Äôt Made the Alias Yet You can create it now: ### Create the Alias 1. Go to `Firewall > Aliases > IP` 2. Click ‚ûï Add 3. Fill in: - **Name**: `ProtonVPN_Clients` - **Type**: `Host(s)` - **IP or FQDN**: `10.69.0.100` - Description: ‚ÄúDevices routed through Proton VPN‚Äù 4. Save & Apply Now, when building firewall rules: - Choose **‚ÄúSingle host or alias‚Äù** - Type in/select: `ProtonVPN_Clients` for **Source** --- This gives you full flexibility: - ‚úÖ Add/remove IPs from the alias to control routing - ‚úÖ No need to touch firewall rules every time - ‚úÖ Your DNS and gateway rules only apply when the IP is in the alias Let me know if you‚Äôd like help verifying or testing the alias-based routing in pfSense ‚Äî happy to assist with diagnostics too.

User: I am no longer able to route 10.69.0.100 (Desktop) over Proton VPN) because I think that I made an error adjusting my rules. Here is the list: After placing the 4 rules that you provided my LAN rules look like this from the top: 1. pfBlocker 2 Anti-lockout Rule: Desktop to GUI 3 Allow SSH to pfSense 4 Block WAN DNS for VPN - your rule #1 5 Allow DNS to Proton DNS - Your rule #2 6 VPN client traffic via Proton VPN - Your rule #3 7 Default LAN Allow - Your rule #4 8. Allow LAN.net to TRUENAS.net 9. Allow LAN.net to WEBSERVERS.net 10. Default allow LAN to ANY rule - I believe that this rule is redundant as it is currently disabled?

Assistant: Thanks for the detailed breakdown ‚Äî that helps a lot. Your rule order mostly looks good, and yes ‚Äî rule priority in pfSense **matters**, because it's evaluated **top to bottom**, stopping at the first match. Let‚Äôs walk through what‚Äôs likely going wrong and how to fix it. --- ## üîç What Might Be Happening It sounds like **rule #6 (VPN client traffic via Proton VPN)** is either: - Not matching the traffic from `10.69.0.100`, **OR** - Matching but the gateway is failing Meanwhile, rule #7 (`Default LAN allow`) could be catching unmatched traffic and sending it over WAN instead of VPN ‚Äî though you‚Äôve confirmed the last default rule is disabled. --- ## ‚úÖ Step-by-Step Fix & Diagnostic Plan ### ‚úÖ Step 1: Verify Your Alias - Go to `Firewall > Aliases > IP` - Open `ProtonVPN_Clients` - Make sure `10.69.0.100` is still listed (it might have been removed or typo‚Äôd) --- ### ‚úÖ Step 2: Review Rule #6 Closely In `Firewall > Rules > LAN`, check **Rule #6** (`VPN client traffic via Proton VPN`) and verify: - **Source**: `ProtonVPN_Clients` alias - **Destination**: `any` - **Protocol**: `any` - **Gateway**: set to your VPN gateway (should be something like `Proton_VPN_GW`) - ‚úÖ Also: make sure it is **enabled** - üí° Click the üñâ (Edit) button and double-check that **log packets** is checked (temporarily), so we can use it in step 4 --- ### ‚úÖ Step 3: Confirm Your VPN Gateway Go to `System > Routing > Gateways` - Make sure you have a gateway for **Proton_VPN** (`ovpnc1`) - It should be **online** and reachable - If it's marked as **down**, traffic will silently fall back to default (WAN) üí° If the VPN gateway isn't listed, or shows as down, it must be fixed first. Sometimes pfSense kills the gateway if your VPN credentials expire or reconnect fails. --- ### ‚úÖ Step 4: Use the pfSense Logs to See What‚Äôs Happening Go to: **Status > System Logs > Firewall** - Filter: `Source IP: 10.69.0.100` - Look for: - **Blocked traffic** to DNS (port 53) or anything unexpected - **Which rule is matching traffic** ‚Äî it should say something like `@rulenum VPN client traffic via Proton VPN` This will confirm if rule #6 is **matching**, or if another rule is catching it first. If nothing is logged: - Go to `Diagnostics > States` - Filter by `10.69.0.100` - Click the trash can to **clear states**, just to make sure pfSense isn't still using old gateway routes --- ### ‚úÖ Step 5: Confirm NAT (If Using Manual Outbound NAT) If you've enabled **Manual Outbound NAT** (for more control), you'll need a NAT rule for Proton VPN too. Go to: `Firewall > NAT > Outbound` - Confirm it's **Manual** or **Hybrid** - Look for a rule: - **Interface**: `ovpnc1` - **Source**: `10.69.0.100` or `ProtonVPN_Clients` - **Destination**: `any` - **Translation address**: `Interface address` If that rule doesn‚Äôt exist, VPN traffic won‚Äôt get NAT‚Äôd, and won‚Äôt return properly ‚Üí no internet. --- ## üßπ Optional: Clean Up Unused Rules - Rule #10: ‚ÄúDefault allow LAN to ANY‚Äù ‚Äî yes, this is redundant if disabled. Leave it that way. - pfBlockerNG rule ‚Äî leave at the top - You could move rules #8‚Äì9 **below rule #6** (VPN traffic), or restrict them to `!ProtonVPN_Clients` if you want to exclude VPN traffic from accessing TrueNAS/webservers --- ## üìå Recap: Critical Pieces to Check | Checkpoint | Should Be | |-----------------------------------|---------------------------------| | `ProtonVPN_Clients` Alias | Contains `10.69.0.100` | | Rule #6 Gateway | Set to `Proton_VPN` gateway | | Gateway Status | **Online** | | Outbound NAT Rule for VPN | Exists for `ovpnc1` + 10.69.0.100 | | Firewall Logs | Show traffic hitting rule #6 | | State Table | Cleared after making rule changes | --- Want to send a screenshot of your Rule #6 or NAT settings (with private info blurred if needed)? I can double-check the settings visually too.

User: In Step 4 I confirmed that there is a block on the log when I switch to VPN on the desktop by adding it's IP to the alias. The block repeats indicating that the Interface = WAN, Rule = Block IPv4 link-local (1000000101), Source = 169.254.100.1:50760, Destination = 239.255.255.250:1900 and Protocol = UDP?

Assistant: Great catch ‚Äî and that log entry explains *a lot*. Let‚Äôs break it down, then circle back to your VPN routing issue. --- ## üß† What That Blocked Packet Means The log entry: ``` Interface = WAN Rule = Block IPv4 link-local (1000000101) Source = 169.254.100.1:50760 Destination = 239.255.255.250:1900 Protocol = UDP ``` This is **normal behavior** ‚Äî and **not the cause** of your Proton VPN issue. ### ‚úÖ What it actually is: - **169.254.x.x** = link-local IP ‚Üí a fallback Windows uses when DHCP fails or for local auto-config. - **239.255.255.250:1900** = **SSDP** (Simple Service Discovery Protocol), used for things like: - UPnP - DLNA - Windows device discovery pfSense **always blocks link-local and multicast traffic** on the WAN by default ‚Äî that‚Äôs what rule `1000000101` is. --- ## üí° So Why Is This Helpful? It proves your desktop **is generating traffic**, but we‚Äôre seeing **nothing else hit your VPN routing rules** ‚Äî which means: ### üí£ The Real Problem: Your **VPN rule (#6)** isn‚Äôt matching outbound traffic. That means: - The alias might not be working correctly - The rule might be missing something - Or **your NAT rules** aren‚Äôt translating the traffic correctly to the VPN tunnel --- ## ‚úÖ Let‚Äôs Zero In On the Fix ### ‚úÖ 1. Confirm the Rule Order Again Please confirm this order still exists under `Firewall > Rules > LAN`: | Rule # | Description | Notes | |--------|------------------------------------|----------------------------------------| | 4 | Block WAN DNS for VPN | ‚úÖ Source: `ProtonVPN_Clients`, port 53 | | 5 | Allow DNS to Proton DNS | ‚úÖ Source: `ProtonVPN_Clients`, port 53, GW: Proton | | 6 | VPN client traffic via Proton VPN | ‚úÖ Source: `ProtonVPN_Clients`, **any**, GW: Proton | | 7 | Default LAN allow | ‚úÖ Source: any, GW: default or auto | ‚Üí Make sure **rule 6 is enabled**, and **gateway is correctly selected** (your `ovpnc1` gateway) --- ### ‚úÖ 2. Go to NAT and Verify VPN NAT Rule Exists This is **the most common reason** VPN traffic seems to fail: no NAT rule = no return path. Go to `Firewall > NAT > Outbound`: - Confirm it‚Äôs set to **Manual** or **Hybrid** - Look for a rule: - **Interface**: `Proton_VPN` (ovpnc1) - **Source**: `10.69.0.100` or `ProtonVPN_Clients` or `LAN net` - **Translation Address**: Interface Address If it‚Äôs **missing**, do this: ### ‚ûï Add Manual Outbound NAT Rule: 1. Interface: `Proton_VPN` 2. Source: `10.69.0.100/32` (or your alias if allowed) 3. Destination: any 4. Translation Address: **Interface Address** 5. Description: `NAT for Proton VPN client` Save & Apply Changes. --- ### ‚úÖ 3. Clear States After Changes After adjusting rules: - Go to `Diagnostics > States` - Filter for: `10.69.0.100` - Click üóëÔ∏è to **remove old sessions** that may be tied to the WAN gateway --- ### ‚úÖ 4. (Optional) Use Packet Capture If it's still not working, try this: - Go to `Diagnostics > Packet Capture` - Interface: `ovpnc1` - Host Address: `10.69.0.100` - Start capture - Try pinging a site or browsing from the desktop - Stop capture If nothing shows up: traffic is never hitting the tunnel ‚Üí rule or NAT issue If you see packets but no reply: probably NAT issue or tunnel down --- ## ‚úÖ Final Checklist | ‚úÖ | Item | |----|------| | Alias `ProtonVPN_Clients` contains `10.69.0.100` | | Rule #6 has correct gateway: `Proton_VPN` | | NAT rule exists on `ovpnc1` for source `10.69.0.100` | | Firewall states are cleared after changes | | VPN gateway (`Proton_VPN`) shows as **Online** under `System > Routing > Gateways` | | No other floating rules interfering with routing | --- Would you like to screenshot or list your current **NAT outbound rules** and **Rule #6 settings**? I‚Äôd be happy to review them line-by-line with you.

User: In 2. Go to NAT and Verify VPN NAT Rule Exists, I have a mapping for PROTO_VPN, address family = IPv4, Protocol = any, Source = Network - Route_Out_Over_VPN (which is my alias for VPN) -/32, Destination = any -/24, Address > Translation = Interface Address.

Assistant: Perfect ‚Äî thanks for sharing that NAT rule detail. Let‚Äôs break it down to make sure it‚Äôs solid: --- ## üß† Breakdown of Your NAT Rule | Field | Value | ‚úÖ / ‚ö†Ô∏è | |--------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------|----------| | **Interface** | `PROTON_VPN` (ovpnc1) | ‚úÖ | | **Address Family** | IPv4 | ‚úÖ | | **Protocol** | any | ‚úÖ | | **Source** | **Network:** `Route_Out_Over_VPN` (your alias) `-/32` | ‚ö†Ô∏è *(likely issue)* | | **Destination** | any `/24` | ‚ö†Ô∏è *(unusual subnet)* | | **Translation** | Interface Address | ‚úÖ | --- ### ‚ö†Ô∏è Issues Identified #### üîπ 1. **Source CIDR = /32 for an Alias** If your alias `Route_Out_Over_VPN` contains multiple IPs, using `/32` assumes it's just **one host** ‚Äî and may not match properly if it‚Äôs treated as a **network**. ‚úÖ **Fix:** - Change **Source** from `Route_Out_Over_VPN /32` to simply `Route_Out_Over_VPN` (do not apply any `/CIDR` mask if you're using an alias ‚Äî pfSense will handle that) --- #### üîπ 2. **Destination = any `/24`** This is odd. `any` is usually left **without a CIDR**, or it‚Äôs explicitly `0.0.0.0/0` ‚úÖ **Fix:** - Change **Destination** to just `any` (this allows NAT to work for all outbound destinations over VPN) --- ### ‚úÖ Corrected NAT Rule Should Be: - **Interface**: `PROTON_VPN` - **Protocol**: any - **Source**: `Route_Out_Over_VPN` *(alias, no /32 or /24)* - **Destination**: `any` - **Translation**: Interface address üí° Description: `NAT for VPN clients` --- ## ‚ú® Bonus Tip: Logging & Testing - You can **enable logging** on that NAT rule to confirm it‚Äôs being used. - After saving, go to: - `Diagnostics > States` and clear sessions for `10.69.0.100` - Try browsing the web from the desktop - Visit [ipleak.net](https://ipleak.net) to see if traffic goes through Proton - Check NAT logs if needed --- ## ‚úÖ Summary Action Plan 1. **Edit NAT Rule** - Remove `/32` from alias - Change destination to `any` 2. **Clear states** for your desktop 3. **Test routing & DNS leak again** Let me know if you'd like help verifying the rule syntax or if you want a quick firewall + NAT summary dump to confirm everything's tight.

User: Okay, we need to back up a bit. In the Setup Overview you provided 4 rules to place in the LAN rules. After restoring pfSense to a previous backup, I just added these 4 rules to LAN and completed the DNS Resolver Tweak. I could not reach the VPN DNS, I assume. I disabled the first rule that you provided: "Rule 1 ‚Äì Block DNS from VPN clients to WAN" and I was able to reach ipleak.net where it showed only my VPN IP and not my ISP address. It still shows things like Detected information, System information, Screen information, Plugins information, Mime-Types information and HTTP Request Headers

Assistant: Thanks for the clear summary ‚Äî you're troubleshooting this like a champ üëè. Let's break things down and clean up the confusion so your setup works reliably *without leaks* and is easy to manage as you switch VPN routing on and off. --- ## ‚úÖ You're in a Good Spot - You restored pfSense from a backup (smart move) - Re-added the 4 key LAN rules for VPN control - DNS Resolver is configured to only use `Proton_VPN` (`ovpnc1`) for outbound DNS - After disabling **Rule 1 (Block DNS to WAN)**, you're successfully reaching `ipleak.net`, and **only the Proton VPN IP shows** (‚úÖ no IP leak) - But you're unsure about all the **browser info** still showing on `ipleak.net` --- ## üß† Let's Clarify What's Happening ### üîπ What Rule 1 Does: ```text "Block DNS from VPN clients to WAN" ``` This prevents DNS queries (port 53) from reaching any server **except** those explicitly allowed via other rules (like Rule 2 to Proton DNS). When it's **enabled**, your desktop fails DNS lookups ‚Üí which means your DNS query isn't getting out via Rule 2 (the allow rule) or through pfSense's DNS Resolver. --- ## ‚úÖ Fix This Cleanly ‚Äî Two Good Options --- ### ‚úÖ Option A: Use pfSense DNS Resolver for VPN Clients If your desktop is using `10.69.0.1` (pfSense) as its DNS server ‚Äî as your `ipconfig /all` showed ‚Äî and **you want to keep that**, then: 1. **Make sure Rule 2 (Allow DNS to Proton DNS)** is **not needed** ‚Äî because the DNS Resolver will handle it 2. Then, Rule 1 (Block WAN DNS) **should be re-enabled** 3. Most importantly, in **DNS Resolver**, make sure: - `Outgoing Interface`: set to **only** `Proton_VPN` (ovpnc1) - DNS Resolver is **enabled and running** This way, when `10.69.0.100` makes a DNS query to `10.69.0.1`, pfSense: - Accepts it on LAN - Forwards it **out through the VPN**, never via WAN ### ‚úÖ Option B: Use Proton DNS Directly From the Client If you‚Äôd rather **skip using pfSense for DNS** and go direct from the desktop to Proton DNS: - Set the DNS server on your desktop to `162.252.172.57` instead of `10.69.0.1` - Keep Rule 1 enabled (blocks WAN DNS leaks) - Rule 2 (Allow DNS to Proton DNS) becomes essential üí°This avoids relying on pfSense as a DNS middleman, but slightly reduces flexibility. --- ## üéØ What About the Other Info on ipleak.net? You're seeing stuff like: - System info - HTTP headers - Screen resolution - Installed fonts/plugins That‚Äôs all **browser fingerprinting** ‚Äî it‚Äôs **not a leak of your real IP or DNS**. It's normal and doesn‚Äôt compromise your VPN routing. **To reduce this:** - Use privacy-focused browsers like Firefox with extensions like: - **uBlock Origin** - **Privacy Badger** - **CanvasBlocker** - Or use **Brave** or **Tor Browser**, which already harden this info --- ## ‚úÖ Summary: Your Action Steps If you're using pfSense (`10.69.0.1`) as your desktop DNS: 1. ‚úÖ Re-enable Rule 1 (Block WAN DNS) 2. ‚ùå You can delete or disable Rule 2 (direct to Proton DNS), unless you're manually setting it on the desktop 3. ‚úÖ Confirm DNS Resolver is bound to `Proton_VPN` interface only 4. ‚úÖ Confirm desktop DNS is set to `10.69.0.1` 5. üßπ Clear browser cache/DNS: ```powershell ipconfig /flushdns ``` Then visit [ipleak.net](https://ipleak.net) again: - You should **still see the VPN IP** - You should **not see your ISP IP** - You will see **browser/device fingerprinting**, which is not a DNS or IP leak --- Want to go over the exact Resolver settings or desktop DNS config? I'm happy to walk through either path.

Assistant:

Assistant: Yes, I was able to extract the data from your spreadsheet. Here's a summary of what I found under the **"LAN Rules"** section: ### LAN Rules Overview: | # | States | Protocol | Source | Destination | Port | Gateway | Description | |---|--------------|----------|------------------|------------------|--------------|-------------------|---------------------------------------------| | 1 | 3/2.31 MiB | IPv4 TCP | 10.69.0.100 | LAN address | 443 (HTTPS) | * | Anti-Lockout Rule: Desktop access to GUI | | 2 | 0/9 KiB | IPv4 TCP | 10.69.0.100 | LAN address | 22 (SSH) | * | Allow SSH to pfSense from desktop | | 3 | 0/0 B | IPv4 * | Laptop_Devices | * | * | PROTON_VPN_VPNV4 | **TEMP: Route Laptop devices via Proton_VPN** | | 4 | 0/0 B | IPv4 * | * | pfB_PRI1_v4 | * | * | pfB_PRI1_v4 | | 5 | 0/870.38 MiB | IPv4 * | LAN net | TRUENAS net | * | * | (no description) | | 6 | 0/780 B | IPv4 * | LAN net | WEBSERVERS net | * | * | (no description) | | 7 | 0/0 B | IPv4 * | Route_Out_Over_VPN | * | * | PROTON_VPN_VPNV4 | IP's to be routed over VPN | | 8 | 190/-7.9 MiB | IPv4 * | LAN net | * | * | * | Default allow LAN to any rule | --- The TEMP rule for routing the laptop (rule #3) appears configured as follows: - **Source:** `Laptop_Devices` (assuming this alias includes both LAN and WiFi IPs or MACs) - **Gateway:** `PROTON_VPN_VPNV4` To fully confirm that everything is set up correctly, I‚Äôll now check the other sheets (PROTON_VPN rules, OpenVPN clients, and client statistics). Let‚Äôs extract those next.

Assistant: Here's a breakdown of the remaining sections in your spreadsheet and how they're configured: --- ### ‚úÖ **PROTON_VPN Rules** Only one rule is listed here: | States | Protocol | Source | Destination | Gateway | Description | |--------|----------|--------|-------------|-------------------|-------------------------------------------| | 0/0 B | IPv4 * | * | pfB_PRI1_v4 | * | `pfB_PRI1_v4` (blocklist or filter rule) | This suggests you might be using `pfBlockerNG` or similar to restrict traffic through the VPN interface. --- ### ‚úÖ **OpenVPN Clients** | Interface | Protocol | Server | Description | |-----------|----------|------------------------|-------------| | WAN | UDP4 | 149.88.27.206 :1194 | Proton_VPN | Other relevant OpenVPN details: - **Mode:** Peer to Peer (SSL/TLS) - **Ciphers:** AES-256-GCM, CHACHA20-POLY1305 - **Digest:** SHA1 --- ### ‚úÖ **Client Instance Statistics** | Name | Status | Last Change | Local Address | Virtual Address | Remote Host | Bytes Sent | Bytes Received | |----------|------------------------|--------------------------|------------------|------------------|----------------------|-------------|-----------------| | ovpnc1 | Connected (Success) | Tue Mar 25 19:29:27 2025 | 10.0.0.20:32026 | 10.96.0.40 | 149.88.27.206:1194 | 1.77 MiB | 17 KiB | So yes ‚Äî the VPN is connected and live. --- ### Summary & Recommendations: ‚úÖ **You did everything correctly** to send the Laptop traffic through ProtonVPN: - Rule #3 on LAN uses alias `Laptop_Devices` and sets the gateway to `PROTON_VPN_VPNV4`. - A mirrored rule is present on the Proton VPN interface. - OpenVPN client is active and routing traffic (as shown in Client Statistics). üîç **Next steps to verify fully working**: 1. **Check that "Laptop_Devices" alias includes all relevant IPs** ‚Äî both wired and WiFi. 2. **Confirm DNS is routed through VPN** ‚Äî go to `System > General Setup` and verify the DNS servers are pushed by the VPN or routed through it. 3. **Use a browser on the laptop and visit [https://ipleak.net](https://ipleak.net)** to check IP, DNS, and WebRTC leak. If you want me to check the alias content or verify anything else, feel free to upload or describe it!

User: I disabled the pfBlocker rule in the PROTO_VPN rules and tested again. No go. Do I need to add a rule to PROTO_VPN? I do not quite understand the Local Address and the Virtual Address. Local Address 10.0.0.20:32026 Virtual Address 10.96.0.40 Remote Host 149.88.27.206:1194

Assistant: Thanks for the update ‚Äî you're very close, and I can help clarify what‚Äôs going on here and guide you through the next steps. --- ### üîç Let‚Äôs decode those addresses first: | Field | Meaning | |------------------|---------| | **Local Address: 10.0.0.20:32026** | This is the IP of your **pfSense WAN interface**, or wherever the VPN is connecting from (your external IP before the tunnel). The port (`:32026`) is used for the OpenVPN connection. | | **Virtual Address: 10.96.0.40** | This is the **IP address pfSense receives from ProtonVPN**. It‚Äôs the internal IP assigned to your pfSense box **inside the VPN tunnel**. Think of this as the new source IP when traffic exits through the VPN. | | **Remote Host: 149.88.27.206:1194** | This is the **ProtonVPN server‚Äôs external IP and OpenVPN port (1194)**. You connect *to* this to establish the VPN. | So when your laptop sends traffic through the VPN, pfSense should: 1. NAT (masquerade) the laptop's traffic using **10.96.0.40**. 2. Send it out the **VPN interface**, to ProtonVPN. 3. Receive return traffic back through the tunnel. --- ### ‚úÖ **You do need a rule on the PROTON_VPN interface** Even though the **LAN rule directs traffic to use the VPN gateway**, **pfSense will block all incoming traffic on any interface by default unless explicitly allowed**. So yes ‚Äî if there's no **"allow" rule** on the `PROTON_VPN` interface, **outbound traffic via VPN will get silently dropped**. --- ### ‚úÖ Here's what to do: 1. **Go to `Firewall > Rules > PROTON_VPN`** 2. **Add a new rule:** - **Action:** Pass - **Interface:** `PROTON_VPN` - **Address Family:** IPv4 - **Protocol:** Any - **Source:** Any (or you can limit to `Laptop_Devices` if you want extra safety) - **Destination:** Any - **Description:** `Allow traffic out PROTON_VPN` 3. **Place this rule above any block or pfBlocker rules** on the interface. 4. **Apply changes**, then test again on the laptop using [https://ipleak.net](https://ipleak.net). --- ### üîÅ Optional for better security: If you want to ensure **only Laptop traffic goes over the VPN**, and **nothing leaks via WAN** if the VPN fails: - In **Firewall > NAT > Outbound**, make sure: - You‚Äôre using **Manual Outbound NAT** mode. - You have a rule for traffic from `Laptop_Devices` going out via `PROTON_VPN` interface using `10.96.0.40`. - Enable the **"Kill Switch"** approach by: - Adding a **floating rule or LAN block rule** that blocks `Laptop_Devices` from using the WAN gateway if the VPN is down. Let me know if you'd like help setting that up too ‚Äî I can guide you rule by rule.

Assistant: Thanks ‚Äî you're giving me a clear picture. You‚Äôve done a lot of the heavy lifting already. Based on what you just described, here's a breakdown of what‚Äôs missing and what to check next: --- ## ‚úÖ You're **very** close. Let's walk through the checklist. --- ### üîß 1. **Outbound NAT MUST include a rule for PROTON_VPN** You mentioned your Outbound NAT shows only one rule for Plex and WAN. That‚Äôs not enough. To route traffic from your **Laptop_Devices** over the VPN tunnel, **you need an Outbound NAT rule for interface `PROTON_VPN`**, specifically for the laptop IPs. Here‚Äôs how to do it: #### üîÅ Configure **Manual Outbound NAT** (if not already): - Go to **Firewall > NAT > Outbound** - At the top, select **"Manual Outbound NAT rule generation"** - Click **Save** and **Apply Changes** --- #### ‚ûï Now **add a rule**: 1. **Click ‚ÄúAdd‚Äù** (near top of the list). 2. **Interface:** `PROTON_VPN` 3. **Protocol:** Any 4. **Source:** **Single host or alias** ‚Üí enter `Laptop_Devices` 5. **Destination:** Any 6. **Translation Address:** Interface address (should default to `10.96.0.40` ‚Äî the VPN's internal IP) 7. **Description:** `NAT Laptop_Devices over PROTON_VPN` ‚úÖ **Save and Apply Changes** --- ### üîç 2. Confirm Routing Is Actually Through VPN Let‚Äôs ensure the **firewall rule** is directing traffic over the VPN: - Go to **Firewall > Rules > LAN** - Your **TEMP** rule for `Laptop_Devices` should: - Be above the default ‚ÄúAllow LAN to any‚Äù rule. - Set **Gateway** to `PROTON_VPN_VPNV4`. ‚úÖ Sounds like you‚Äôve done this ‚Äî just double-check order and gateway assignment. --- ### üß™ 3. Test with `Diagnostics > Packet Capture` You can watch traffic to see where it's going: - Go to **Diagnostics > Packet Capture** - Interface: `PROTON_VPN` - Filter expression: `host 10.69.0.100` (or whatever your laptop IP is) - Click Start - On the laptop, try browsing to any site - Stop the capture and download/view it ‚û° If you see no packets ‚Äî traffic isn‚Äôt making it out the VPN interface. --- ### üîí 4. Optional: Block WAN access as a kill switch After we get VPN working, we can block `Laptop_Devices` from using the WAN in case VPN drops. Let‚Äôs get it routing first. --- ### üß† TL;DR Fix Plan - ‚úÖ Add a **manual Outbound NAT rule** for `Laptop_Devices` on `PROTON_VPN` - ‚úÖ Ensure **manual mode** is enabled for Outbound NAT - ‚úÖ Verify **LAN firewall rule** uses correct **gateway** - ‚úÖ Verify **VPN firewall rule** allows traffic - ‚úÖ Use **Packet Capture** to confirm routing Once you do the NAT rule and double-check the rest, you *should* be up and running. Want me to write out a checklist for testing or setting up the kill switch after this?

I ran https://ipleak.net nd it showed me my PROTON Switzerland connection. However, It detected 2 Servers, United States- Washington - Comcast -7922 (which is my ISP) and My IP Address from Comcast. Why is this leaking?

Assistant: Ah ‚Äî thank you for the clear follow-up. You're *definitely on the right track now*, and it's awesome that your traffic is routing through ProtonVPN and confirming the Swiss IP on ipleak.net. --- ## üö® But yes ‚Äî if ipleak.net is still seeing your **Comcast IP** or **DNS servers in Washington**, then **you're experiencing a DNS leak**. --- ### üîç Why This Happens Even if **all your web traffic** is routed through the VPN tunnel (thanks to the gateway and NAT rules), your **DNS queries** might still go out via the default WAN interface **unless explicitly routed otherwise**. That‚Äôs why ipleak is showing: - ‚úÖ The correct ProtonVPN IP (good!) - ‚ùå Your **ISP‚Äôs IP and/or DNS server** (leak!) --- ### ‚úÖ How to Fix It ‚Äî DNS Leak Protection on pfSense #### Step 1: **Force pfSense to use ProtonVPN‚Äôs DNS** - Go to **System > General Setup** - Scroll to the **DNS Server Settings** - Remove **any existing DNS servers** that belong to Comcast (or 1.1.1.1, Google, etc.) - Add DNS server(s) from ProtonVPN: - For example: - `10.96.0.1` (sometimes your VPN provider offers a private DNS via the tunnel) - Or ProtonDNS: `162.252.172.57` and `149.154.159.92` - Under "DNS Server Override", **uncheck**: - ‚úÖ *Allow DNS server list to be overridden by DHCP/PPP on WAN* - ‚úÖ **Check** ‚ÄúDo not use the DNS Forwarder or Resolver as a DNS server for the firewall‚Äù ‚úÖ **Click Save** --- #### Step 2: **Ensure laptop is using pfSense for DNS ‚Äî not some hardcoded one** Make sure your laptop: - Is **not manually set to 8.8.8.8 or 1.1.1.1** - Is getting its DNS via DHCP from pfSense (usually 10.69.0.1) - You can check this with: - `ipconfig /all` on Windows - `cat /etc/resolv.conf` on Linux or macOS --- #### Step 3: **Optional but Stronger: Use DNS Resolver with forwarding over VPN** If you're using **Unbound (DNS Resolver)**: 1. Go to **Services > DNS Resolver** 2. Scroll down to ‚ÄúOutgoing Network Interfaces‚Äù 3. Set to **only `PROTON_VPN`** (instead of All or WAN) 4. Save and Apply --- ### üß™ After Fixing Clear DNS cache: - On laptop: `ipconfig /flushdns` (Windows), or restart networking on Mac/Linux Then re-run: üëâ [https://ipleak.net](https://ipleak.net) ‚úÖ You should now see: - Only a **ProtonVPN IP** in Switzerland - DNS servers that **match Proton**, not Comcast --- Would you like help building a quick toggle system for the desktop/laptop VPN bypass later? We can use firewall rule groups or tags for that. But DNS fix comes first.

User: how do i clear my DNS cache on my windows 11 laptop?

Assistant: To clear the DNS cache on your **Windows 11** laptop: --- ### üßº **Steps to Flush DNS Cache** 1. **Right-click** the **Start Menu** and select **Windows Terminal (Admin)** ‚Äì or ‚Äì Press `Win + X` and choose **‚ÄúWindows Terminal (Admin)‚Äù** 2. In the terminal window, type the following command and hit **Enter**: ``` ipconfig /flushdns ``` 3. You should see a confirmation message: > Successfully flushed the DNS Resolver Cache. --- That‚Äôs it ‚Äî your DNS cache is now cleared. You can now test DNS again using [https://ipleak.net](https://ipleak.net) or similar tools. Let me know if you also want to check what DNS server your laptop is currently using.

System:

Assistant: To clear your DNS cache on a Windows 11 laptop, follow these steps: --- ### ‚úÖ **Option 1: Use Command Prompt (Quick Method)** 1. **Press `Win + S`** and type: ``` cmd ``` 2. **Right-click** on ‚ÄúCommand Prompt‚Äù and choose **‚ÄúRun as administrator‚Äù** 3. In the Command Prompt window, type: ``` ipconfig /flushdns ``` 4. You should see the confirmation message: > **Successfully flushed the DNS Resolver Cache.** --- ### üßº Optional: Restart your browser or entire system after flushing to ensure no lingering DNS info is cached at the application level. Let me know if you want to verify the DNS servers your laptop is currently using ‚Äî I can walk you through that too.

User: I cleared my DNS on the laptop, rebooted it and connected a LAN connection in addition to the WiFi connection. Both show that they are receiving DNS from 10.69.0.1 (my pfSense firewall) I am now in System > General Setup on pfSense and have cleared my DNS servers. I need to: Enter IP addresses to be used by the system for DNS resolution. These are also used for the DHCP service, DNS Forwarder and DNS Resolver when it has DNS Query Forwarding enabled. Then I need to add an Optional Hostname. Finally I have to add a gateway From the selection of "WAN_DHCP - wan - 10.0.0.1" or "PROTON_VPN_VPN$ - opt6 - 10.96.0.40"?

System:

Assistant: Perfect ‚Äî you‚Äôve done a solid job so far, and you're *right at the point* where the DNS leak fix hinges on the next step. Let‚Äôs walk through this **carefully** so DNS **only** uses ProtonVPN and avoids leaking through WAN. --- ## ‚úÖ Here's What You Should Enter in **System > General Setup** ### 1. **DNS Servers** You need to manually enter DNS servers **that are privacy-respecting and safe to use through the VPN**. You have two good options here: --- ### üîí **Option A: ProtonVPN DNS** If your ProtonVPN connection uses **10.96.0.1** as its internal gateway (which is very common), you can try: - `10.96.0.1` ‚Üí this routes DNS *through the VPN tunnel* **(Try this first)** --- ### üåê **Option B: Public Privacy DNS (like ProtonDNS)** If the above doesn't work or you'd prefer hard-coded privacy DNS, you can use: - `162.252.172.57` - `149.154.159.92` These are ProtonVPN's public DNS servers (ProtonDNS) Or alternatives like: - `9.9.9.9` (Quad9 ‚Äî privacy-focused, no logging) - `1.1.1.1` (Cloudflare ‚Äî fast, privacy-focused) --- ### 2. **Hostname and Domain** - **Hostname:** You can leave this blank or use something simple like `pfSense`. - **Domain:** Leave as default unless you use a custom internal domain. --- ### 3. **Gateway for Each DNS Server** For each DNS server you enter, there‚Äôs a dropdown for **Gateway**. Here's what to do: | DNS Server | Gateway | |---------------------|--------------------------------| | `10.96.0.1` | `PROTON_VPN_VPNV4 - 10.96.0.40` ‚úÖ | | `149.154.159.92` | `PROTON_VPN_VPNV4 - 10.96.0.40` ‚úÖ | | `1.1.1.1` (if used) | `PROTON_VPN_VPNV4` ‚úÖ | | **Never use** | `WAN_DHCP - 10.0.0.1` üö´ | ‚ùå **Do NOT assign WAN as a gateway** for any DNS server ‚Äî that will cause DNS leaks. --- ### 4. **Other Checkboxes (Bottom of Page)** Check these: ‚úÖ **[ ] Allow DNS server list to be overridden by DHCP/PPP on WAN** ‚Üí **UNCHECK** this. ‚úÖ **[‚úì] Do not use the DNS Forwarder or Resolver as a DNS server for the firewall** Click **Save** and **Apply Changes** --- ## üîÅ Final Steps: 1. Go to **Diagnostics > DNS Lookup** - Try resolving `protonvpn.com` ‚Äî confirm DNS queries succeed through your new settings. 2. Go to your **laptop** and test: - `ipconfig /flushdns` again - Reboot browser - Visit [https://ipleak.net](https://ipleak.net) ‚úÖ **You should now see only ProtonVPN IPs and DNS** Let me know what shows up ‚Äî and if you still see Comcast after this, we can dig into Unbound settings or interface binding.

Anti-Lockout Rule Explanation

System:

System:

User: Can you remind me why there is an Anti-Lockout Rule at the top of the LAN rules for ports 443 and 80?

Assistant:

Assistant: Yes ‚Äî the **Anti-Lockout Rule** in pfSense exists to prevent you from accidentally locking yourself out of the web interface (GUI) while configuring firewall rules. Here‚Äôs why it‚Äôs there, specifically for **ports 443 (HTTPS)** and **80 (HTTP)** on the **LAN interface**: --- ### üîí **Purpose of the Anti-Lockout Rule** - When you're working on the firewall, especially from the LAN side, it's easy to make a mistake and block access to the web interface. - If you block access to **port 443 or 80**, and you're managing pfSense via the web GUI, you could lose access and have to physically go to the device or use console access to fix it. - To protect against this, pfSense automatically creates a rule near the top of the **LAN rules list** allowing access **from the LAN subnet to the LAN interface address on ports 80 and 443**. --- ### üß† What the Rule Looks Like: - **Interface:** LAN - **Source:** LAN subnet - **Destination:** This firewall (LAN address) - **Ports:** 80 and 443 (HTTP and HTTPS) - **Description:** "Anti-Lockout Rule" --- ### üõ† Can You Disable It? - Yes ‚Äî under **System ‚Üí Advanced ‚Üí Admin Access**, there's a checkbox to **disable the anti-lockout rule**. - But if you do, you should **immediately create your own rule** to allow access to the web interface, or you'll lose access unless you have console/SSH access set up. --- ### üí° When You Might Disable It: - You're locking down all LAN access very tightly and want to control GUI access only through VPN or a specific admin IP. - You already have specific rules allowing admin access and want to avoid any broad exceptions. --- So in short, the Anti-Lockout Rule is just a safety net to ensure you don‚Äôt lock yourself out of pfSense while managing it from the LAN side.

User: If and when I create a temporary rule for 10.69.0.14, my desktop computer, if I place that rule at the top, can I lock myself out of the GUI?

Assistant: Great question ‚Äî and the answer depends on **what exactly your temporary rule for `10.69.0.14` does**. --- ### ‚úÖ **If your rule *allows* traffic from 10.69.0.14 to the pfSense web GUI:** > **Example:** > - **Source:** `10.69.0.14` > - **Destination:** `This firewall (LAN address)` > - **Port:** `443` > - **Action:** `Pass` Placing this at the top **will not lock you out** ‚Äî in fact, it ensures your desktop can access the GUI. --- ### ‚ö†Ô∏è **But if your rule *blocks* traffic (explicitly or implicitly):** > **Example:** > - **Source:** `10.69.0.14` > - **Destination:** `any` or `This firewall (LAN)` > - **Port:** `any` or includes port `443` > - **Action:** `Block` or `Reject` And you place this **above** the Anti-Lockout Rule, **then yes**, you can absolutely lock yourself out, **even with the Anti-Lockout Rule still enabled**. pfSense processes rules **top-down**, so if a block hits before the anti-lockout pass rule, access is denied. --- ### üîç TL;DR: - **Temporary ALLOW rule for your IP at the top:** ‚úÖ Safe. - **Temporary BLOCK rule that hits GUI ports (80/443) for your IP at the top:** ‚ùå You can lock yourself out. - **Order matters** ‚Äî topmost matching rule wins. --- If you're ever unsure, a good tip is to **create a temporary "Allow" rule for your IP at the very top**, so no matter what you‚Äôre testing further down, you won‚Äôt lose access. Want help crafting that rule?

User: I would like to create a rule using an Alias for 10.69.102 - Laptop_LAN and 10.69.0.103 - Laptop_WIFI. I want this rule to temporaily direct trafffic to the Proton_VPN gateway. I also need an Anti-Lockout rule which will work with this temporary redirect

System:

Assistant: Perfect ‚Äî you‚Äôre looking to temporarily force two devices (your laptop on LAN and Wi-Fi) through your Proton_VPN gateway **without locking yourself out of pfSense**. Here‚Äôs how to set that up cleanly and safely: --- ## ‚úÖ Step 1: Create an Alias for the Devices Go to: **Firewall ‚Üí Aliases ‚Üí IP** - **Name:** `Laptop_Devices` - **Type:** `Host(s)` - **Description:** `LAN and WiFi IPs for laptop` - **Add:** - `10.69.0.102` (Laptop_LAN) - `10.69.0.103` (Laptop_WIFI) Save and apply changes. --- ## ‚úÖ Step 2: Create a Temporary Redirect Rule Go to: **Firewall ‚Üí Rules ‚Üí LAN** (and do the same in your VLAN if needed) - **Action:** Pass - **Interface:** LAN - **Protocol:** Any - **Source:** `Alias ‚Üí Laptop_Devices` - **Destination:** any - **Advanced ‚Üí Gateway:** Select `Proton_VPN` - **Description:** `TEMP: Route Laptop devices via Proton_VPN` - **Position:** Drag this rule **to the top**, above your default "Allow LAN to any" rule. üí° **Pro Tip:** If this is the only VPN rule, make sure your **Outbound NAT** supports it too. I can help verify that if you want. --- ## ‚úÖ Step 3: Protect Yourself with a Temporary Anti-Lockout Rule Now add a second temporary rule *just above* the Proton VPN rule: - **Action:** Pass - **Interface:** LAN - **Protocol:** TCP - **Source:** `Your desktop IP ‚Üí 10.69.0.14` - **Destination:** `This firewall` - **Destination Port:** `HTTPS (443)` - **Description:** `TEMP: Anti-Lockout for GUI access from desktop` - **Advanced ‚Üí Gateway:** **Do not select anything** ‚Äî let it use the default WAN gateway. üëÄ This guarantees your desktop (10.69.0.14) can still access the GUI **via WAN**, bypassing the VPN redirect rule below. --- ## ‚úÖ Rule Order (Top to Bottom) 1. `TEMP: Anti-Lockout for GUI access from desktop (10.69.0.14)` 2. `TEMP: Route Laptop devices via Proton_VPN` 3. [any other LAN rules like allow LAN to any] --- ## ‚úÖ When You‚Äôre Done - Simply **disable or delete** the temporary rules. - pfSense will go back to routing traffic normally. --- Would you like a matching rule for Wi-Fi (VLAN interface), or help ensuring the VPN gateway is working properly with NAT and policy routing?

User: I currently have an anti-lockout rule at the top of the LAN rules Action: Pass Interface: LAN Protocol: *P Source: * port * Destination: LAN Address Destination Port: 443 80 Gateway * Queue * Schedule Description - Anti-Lockout Rule In the Actions column there is just a gear icon. Rhere is not the normal 6 icons for disabling, copying, editing thrash, and Kill States. I cannot find it's origin?

Assistant: Great observation ‚Äî what you‚Äôre seeing is **pfSense‚Äôs built-in Anti-Lockout Rule**, and it behaves a little differently from regular user-created rules. Here‚Äôs the full explanation of what‚Äôs going on: --- ### üîí **Why You Only See a Gear Icon** - The rule you're seeing with only a **gear icon** and no edit/trash/disable buttons is **not user-created**. - It‚Äôs the **automatically generated Anti-Lockout Rule** that pfSense inserts to protect GUI access from LAN. - That gear icon is just for showing **details** ‚Äî you can‚Äôt delete, edit, or disable it from the rule list. --- ### üîç **Where It Comes From** - It‚Äôs created when this option is **enabled**: > **System ‚Üí Advanced ‚Üí Admin Access ‚Üí "Disable webConfigurator anti-lockout rule"** - If **unchecked** (default), pfSense auto-creates this rule: - **Source:** any (or LAN subnet, depending on version) - **Destination:** LAN address - **Port:** 443 and 80 - **Action:** Pass - It sits **at the top of the LAN rules list** and can‚Äôt be changed like normal rules. --- ### ‚úÖ **How to Control or Replace It** If you want full control over anti-lockout rules: 1. **Go to:** `System ‚Üí Advanced ‚Üí Admin Access` 2. **Check:** "Disable webConfigurator anti-lockout rule" 3. **Save** 4. Then you can create your **own custom anti-lockout rule** like we discussed earlier. But be very careful ‚Äî once you do this, **you are responsible for ensuring you don‚Äôt block GUI access**, especially if you're forcing devices through VPNs or messing with firewall redirection. --- ### TL;DR - The gear-only rule is **pfSense‚Äôs built-in anti-lockout rule**. - It‚Äôs not editable or removable unless you **explicitly disable the feature** in System ‚Üí Advanced. - If you want to manage access yourself, disable it and make your own rules (as you're already planning to do safely). Want help crafting a full set of rules to safely replace it?

User: Yes please but I have changed my desktop from a dynamic IP of 10.69.0.14 to A Static IP of 10.69.0.100

Assistant: User's desktop now has a static IP address of 10.69.0.100.

Tool: Model set context updated.

Assistant: Perfect! Now that your desktop has a **static IP of 10.69.0.100**, we can safely disable the built-in Anti-Lockout Rule and replace it with a **custom rule** that gives you secure GUI access while still allowing VPN policy routing for other devices. --- ## ‚úÖ Step 1: Disable the Built-in Anti-Lockout Rule Go to: **System ‚Üí Advanced ‚Üí Admin Access** - Check ‚úÖ **‚ÄúDisable webConfigurator anti-lockout rule‚Äù** - Click **Save** ‚ö†Ô∏è Don‚Äôt apply this until your replacement rule (below) is created and working. You can prepare both first. --- ## ‚úÖ Step 2: Create a Custom Anti-Lockout Rule Go to: **Firewall ‚Üí Rules ‚Üí LAN** - **Action:** Pass - **Interface:** LAN - **Protocol:** TCP - **Source:** `10.69.0.100` (your desktop) - **Destination:** `LAN Address` - **Destination Port:** HTTPS (443) - **Gateway:** (leave as default ‚Äì do **not** set Proton_VPN here) - **Description:** `Anti-Lockout Rule: Desktop access to GUI` üí° You can optionally add port **80 (HTTP)** too if you want, or make a second rule for that. **Drag this rule to the top** of your LAN rule list. --- ## ‚úÖ Step 3: (Optional) Allow ICMP/Ping or SSH to pfSense (for fallback access) If you want to be extra safe, you can also allow: - **ICMP Echo (ping)** to LAN Address - **SSH (port 22)** if you‚Äôve enabled SSH access under **System ‚Üí Advanced ‚Üí Secure Shell** This gives you alternate ways to reach the firewall if something goes wrong. --- ## ‚úÖ Step 4: Apply and Test - **Before** disabling the built-in rule, test your new rule by ensuring you can still log into the GUI using your desktop at `10.69.0.100`. - Once confirmed, go disable the built-in rule under **System ‚Üí Advanced ‚Üí Admin Access**. --- Would you like me to help with a matching VPN rule for your laptop devices using the same clean structure?

User: Yes, please

Assistant:

Assistant: Great ‚Äî here‚Äôs a clean, safe way to route your **laptop devices through Proton_VPN** using an alias, while **preserving GUI access** from your desktop (10.69.0.100). --- ## ‚úÖ Step 1: Create Alias for Laptop Devices Go to: **Firewall ‚Üí Aliases ‚Üí IP** - **Name:** `Laptop_Devices` - **Type:** Host(s) - **Description:** `LAN + WiFi IPs for Laptop` - **Entries:** - `10.69.0.102` (Laptop_LAN) - `10.69.0.103` (Laptop_WIFI) Click **Save** and **Apply Changes** --- ## ‚úÖ Step 2: Create VPN Redirect Rule for Laptops Go to: **Firewall ‚Üí Rules ‚Üí LAN** Add a new rule: - **Action:** Pass - **Interface:** LAN - **Protocol:** Any - **Source:** `Alias ‚Üí Laptop_Devices` - **Destination:** any - **Advanced ‚Üí Gateway:** `Proton_VPN` - **Description:** `Route Laptops through Proton_VPN` Click **Save** and **Apply Changes** **Drag this rule BELOW your desktop anti-lockout rule**, but ABOVE any general allow rules like ‚ÄúLAN to any.‚Äù --- ## ‚úÖ Rule Order (Top to Bottom) 1. üîê `Anti-Lockout Rule: Desktop access to GUI (10.69.0.100)` 2. üåê `Route Laptops through Proton_VPN` 3. ‚úÖ (Optional general LAN rule like ‚ÄúLAN to any‚Äù with default gateway) --- ## üõ† Optional Tweaks - If your laptops switch networks often, you can make a second rule on the **VLAN/Wi-Fi interface** with the same alias and settings. - For extra privacy, block **non-VPN traffic fallback** with a **Deny rule** under the VPN rule if Proton_VPN is down. Want help with that? --- Let me know if you'd like to review or set up **Outbound NAT rules** to make sure VPN routing works correctly ‚Äî or if you'd like a script to flip this rule on/off with a schedule or button.

User: ssh marma@10.69.0.1

Assistant: Looks like you're trying to SSH into your pfSense box with: ```bash ssh marma@10.69.0.1 ``` Here‚Äôs a quick checklist to make sure that works: --- ### ‚úÖ Requirements for SSH Access to pfSense 1. **SSH Service Enabled:** - Go to **System ‚Üí Advanced ‚Üí Secure Shell** - Check ‚úÖ **"Enable Secure Shell"** - Choose port (default is `22`) - Optional but recommended: ‚úÖ **"Disable password login for secure shell access"** (use SSH keys) 2. **Firewall Rule Allowing SSH:** - Go to **Firewall ‚Üí Rules ‚Üí LAN** - Add a rule: - **Action:** Pass - **Protocol:** TCP - **Source:** `10.69.0.100` (your desktop) - **Destination:** `LAN Address` - **Port:** `22 (SSH)` - **Description:** `Allow SSH to pfSense from desktop` - Drag this rule **above** any restrictive or VPN-routing rules. 3. **Ensure Username Exists:** - User `marma` must be a valid pfSense user with **Shell access** - Go to **System ‚Üí User Manager ‚Üí Users** - Edit or add `marma` - Set the login shell to `/bin/sh` - Add to the **admin** group if you need full access --- ### üîç Troubleshooting Tips - If you get **‚ÄúConnection refused‚Äù**, the SSH service might not be running or listening on the IP. - If you get **‚ÄúPermission denied‚Äù**, it might be: - Wrong password - Wrong username - SSH key required but not provided --- Want me to walk you through creating the user or configuring keys for secure login?

DHCP Static Mapping Setup

System:

System:

User: I have several hosts that I prefer not to lose thier IP addresses. Should I Static Map them from the LAN service or can I just Static map from the DHCP - Status - Leases?

Assistant:

Assistant: Great question ‚Äî and you're on the right track! If you're using **pfSense** and want to ensure certain hosts always get the same IP address (without manually setting static IPs on each device), you should use **DHCP Static Mappings** (also called DHCP reservations). ### You can do this in either place: #### ‚úÖ **Preferred Method**: **Status ‚Üí DHCP Leases ‚Üí Add Static Mapping** - This is quick and convenient. - Just click the ‚Äú+‚Äù icon next to an existing DHCP lease to create a Static Mapping. - It automatically fills in the MAC address and current IP. - Once saved, pfSense will always assign that IP to that MAC. #### üîß **Alternative Method**: **Services ‚Üí DHCP Server ‚Üí [LAN] ‚Üí Add Static Mapping** - This lets you create a reservation from scratch. - Useful if the host hasn‚Äôt connected yet but you know its MAC address. --- ### Summary: - **Yes**, you *can* just create static mappings from **Status ‚Üí DHCP Leases** ‚Äî it's the easiest way. - It achieves the same result as doing it manually from the DHCP Server settings. - Just make sure you **click ‚ÄúAdd Static Mapping‚Äù**, don‚Äôt just assume the lease will stay forever ‚Äî dynamic leases can change after they expire or reboot. Want help batch-adding a few from your current leases?

User: I would like to batch add: 10.69.0.14 d8:bb:c1:a3:81:06 Msibequiet802 10.69.0.29 da:2f:de:04:c8:e0 John-s-Tab-A8 10.69.0.59 42:43:97:00:5b:8c John-s-S25

Assistant: Perfect ‚Äî here's how you can **batch add static DHCP mappings** in pfSense using your list. --- ### üõ† Option 1: Add via Web GUI (manually, but quick) Go to: **Services ‚Üí DHCP Server ‚Üí [LAN] ‚Üí Static DHCP Mappings for this Interface** For each host, click **‚ÄúAdd‚Äù**, then fill out: | Field | Value | |-------------------|--------------------------------| | **MAC Address** | e.g. `d8:bb:c1:a3:81:06` | | **IP Address** | e.g. `10.69.0.14` | | **Hostname** | e.g. `Msibequiet802` | | **Description** | (optional, but can repeat hostname) | Repeat for each one, then **click Save + Apply Changes**. --- ### üßë‚Äçüíª Option 2: Add via CLI/Config (advanced users) If you're comfortable with SSH and editing config files, you can batch insert these into `/cf/conf/config.xml`, but **use caution** and back up first. --- ### üí° Your Entries Ready for GUI Input: Here are your entries in a clean format to copy/paste into pfSense fields: --- **1. Msibequiet802** - MAC: `d8:bb:c1:a3:81:06` - IP: `10.69.0.14` - Hostname: `Msibequiet802` --- **2. John-s-Tab-A8** - MAC: `da:2f:de:04:c8:e0` - IP: `10.69.0.29` - Hostname: `John-s-Tab-A8` --- **3. John-s-S25** - MAC: `42:43:97:00:5b:8c` - IP: `10.69.0.59` - Hostname: `John-s-S25` --- Let me know if you‚Äôd like a config snippet for the XML file or if you want a custom shell script to automate via the pfSense API.

User: When I try to add static mapping for MsiBequiet802 with 10.69.0.14 I get the error message: The IP address must not be within the DHCP range for this interface.

Assistant: Ah ‚Äî that error is a common gotcha in pfSense. Here's what‚Äôs happening: --- ### üîç **Why you're getting the error:** pfSense won‚Äôt let you assign a **static DHCP mapping** using an IP **inside the DHCP dynamic range** (the pool it hands out automatically), because that could cause IP conflicts. --- ### ‚úÖ **How to fix it:** You have two good options: --- #### **Option 1: Move your static IP outside the DHCP range** Go to: **Services ‚Üí DHCP Server ‚Üí [LAN]** Look for the field: **Range** For example, if your current range is something like: `10.69.0.10` to `10.69.0.100` You can **shrink the range**, like: `10.69.0.20` to `10.69.0.100` That way, `10.69.0.14` is **outside the pool** and available for static mapping. Then go back and re-add the mapping for `10.69.0.14`. --- #### **Option 2: Choose a different IP outside the current DHCP range** If you don‚Äôt want to mess with the DHCP pool, just pick something outside of it. Example: If your current range is `10.69.0.10` ‚Äì `10.69.0.100`, try using: - `10.69.0.2` (if unused), or - `10.69.0.101+` (above the range) --- ### üß† Pro Tip: Keep all your reserved/static IPs **below or above** your DHCP pool to avoid future headaches. A common scheme: - `.1` = gateway (pfSense) - `.2‚Äì.20` = static/reserved - `.21‚Äì.199` = DHCP dynamic pool - `.200‚Äì.254` = static/reserved Want help adjusting your DHCP range or checking which IPs are safe to reserve?

PBR with Temporary Rule

System:

System:

User: I would like to Use a Temporary Firewall Rule with Policy-Based Routing on the LAN.net to route traffic to the PROTON_VPN.net. Can you suggest the rule setup and placement on the LAN.net or can I just move the PROTO_VPN.net rule in the rule order?

Assistant:

Assistant: To temporarily route traffic from your **LAN.net** to **PROTON_VPN.net** using **Policy-Based Routing (PBR)** in pfSense, you can either: ### ‚úÖ Option 1: Add a Temporary Firewall Rule on LAN.net This is the **recommended** approach if you want the change to be temporary or target specific traffic. --- #### üîß Temporary Rule Setup on `LAN.net`: 1. Go to **Firewall > Rules > LAN**. 2. Click **Add** at the top (to place the rule *above* existing ones). 3. Set: - **Action**: Pass - **Interface**: LAN - **Address Family**: IPv4 (or both, as needed) - **Protocol**: Any (or narrow it down) - **Source**: (e.g., your PC's IP, or LAN subnet) - **Destination**: any (or specific destinations if needed) 4. Scroll down to **Advanced Options > Gateway**. - Choose your **PROTON_VPN Gateway** (e.g., `PROTON_VPN_GW`) 5. Add a **description** like `TEMP: Route via PROTON_VPN`. 6. **Save** and **Apply Changes**. #### ‚¨ÜÔ∏è Rule Placement: - **It must be placed above** any other LAN rules that would allow traffic with the default gateway. - You can drag it to the top of the LAN rules list to make sure it takes precedence. --- ### ‚ùå Option 2: Move a `PROTON_VPN.net` Rule If you already have a rule on `PROTON_VPN.net`, **moving it won‚Äôt affect LAN.net**, because: - Firewall rules in pfSense apply per **interface**. - Rules on `PROTON_VPN.net` affect **incoming traffic on that interface**, not **traffic originating from LAN**. So, **moving a rule on the PROTON_VPN interface does not help route LAN traffic**. --- ### üîÅ When You're Done When you want to stop routing LAN traffic via Proton VPN: - **Disable** or **delete** the temporary rule on LAN.net. - pfSense will then fall back to the default gateway (likely your WAN). --- Want help crafting a rule for a specific device or traffic type (like just for a gaming PC or Netflix traffic)?

User: I would like the temporary rule to only apply to the following: IP Address - 10.69.0.14 MAC Address - d8:bb:c1:a3:81:06 Hostname - Msibequiet802

Assistant: Perfect ‚Äî since you want the temporary rule to only apply to a **specific device**, the best way is to match **just its IP address** in the LAN firewall rules. Here's exactly how to set it up: --- ### üîß **Temporary Rule for 10.69.0.14 on LAN.net** 1. Go to **Firewall > Rules > LAN**. 2. Click **Add** (‚òùÔ∏è at the top) to create a rule that‚Äôs evaluated before any others. 3. Set the following: - **Action**: Pass - **Interface**: LAN - **Address Family**: IPv4 - **Protocol**: Any 4. **Source**: - Type: **Single host or alias** - Address: `10.69.0.14` 5. **Destination**: Any (or narrow it down if you only want certain traffic to go through VPN). 6. Scroll to **Advanced Options > Gateway** - Set: `PROTON_VPN_GW` (or whatever your Proton VPN gateway is named) 7. **Description**: `TEMP PBR for Msibequiet802 (10.69.0.14)` 8. **Save** and **Apply Changes** --- ### ‚úÖ Confirming It Works - From Msibequiet802, visit `https://www.whatismyip.com` ‚Äî it should show the Proton VPN public IP address. - From any other LAN device, IP should show your regular WAN IP. --- ### üìù Tips - **MAC address** isn‚Äôt directly usable in pfSense firewall rules, but you‚Äôve already got a **static DHCP mapping** (I assume), since you know the IP/MAC/hostname. - If not, go to **Services > DHCP Server > LAN** and assign `10.69.0.14` to `d8:bb:c1:a3:81:06` to ensure consistency. - If you do this frequently, consider creating an **alias** named something like `Msibequiet802` and referencing that in the source. --- Would you like to schedule this rule to automatically disable later (e.g., tonight at midnight)?

LAN.net Rule Breakdown

System:

System:

User: I am running pfSense+ version 23.05 (arm) Can you decipher this information as presented for my Assignment on the LAN.net I have 8 interfaces: WAN LAN CLIENTS CLIENTSNOVPN WEBSERVERS TRUENAS IOT PROTON_VPN Currently, my LAN.net has the following rules in order from top to bottom States Protocol Source Port Destination Port Gateway Queue Schedule Description Actions 1/31.27 MiB * * * LAN Address 443 80 * * Anti-Lockout Rule 0/0 B IPv4 * * * pfB_PRI1_v4 * * none pfB_PRI1_v4 0/870.10 MiB IPv4 * LAN net * TRUENAS net * * none 0/780 B IPv4 * LAN net * WEBSERVERS net * * none 2/5.20 MiB IPv4 * Route_Out_Over_VPN * * * PROTON_VPN_VPNV4 none IP's to be routed over VPN 125/92.57 MiB IPv4 * LAN net * * * * none Default allow LAN to any rule 0/0 B IPv4 * LAN net * WAN net * * none Default allow LAN to any rule 0/0 B IPv6 * LAN net * * * * none Default allow LAN IPv6 to any rule

Assistant:

Assistant: Thanks for the detailed rundown ‚Äî I‚Äôll help you decipher the rules currently applied to your `LAN.net` interface in pfSense+ 23.05 (ARM). Here's a breakdown and explanation of each rule in plain language, in the order they‚Äôre processed (top to bottom): --- ### **1. Anti-Lockout Rule** ``` Protocol: * | Source: * | Destination: LAN Address | Port: 443, 80 ``` - **Purpose:** Prevents you from locking yourself out of the web interface (HTTP/HTTPS) from LAN. - **Effect:** Allows access to the pfSense web UI on ports 80/443 from within LAN, no matter what other rules are added. - **Status:** 1 connection state using ~31.27 MiB. --- ### **2. pfBlockerNG Rule (pfB_PRI1_v4)** ``` Protocol: IPv4 * | Source: * | Destination: pfB_PRI1_v4 ``` - **Purpose:** Likely a **block or reject rule** created by `pfBlockerNG` to block known bad IPs/domains in the `pfB_PRI1_v4` alias. - **Effect:** Blocks access to IPs/domains in that alias from LAN. - **Status:** 0 connections. Likely triggered occasionally but not currently active. --- ### **3. Allow LAN to TRUENAS net** ``` Protocol: IPv4 * | Source: LAN net | Destination: TRUENAS net ``` - **Purpose:** Allows devices on `LAN` to talk to your `TRUENAS` network/interface. - **Effect:** Enables file sharing, NFS, etc., with the TrueNAS box from LAN. - **Status:** 870.10 MiB sent, so definitely in use. --- ### **4. Allow LAN to WEBSERVERS net** ``` Protocol: IPv4 * | Source: LAN net | Destination: WEBSERVERS net ``` - **Purpose:** Permits devices on LAN to access the subnet/interface for your web servers. - **Effect:** Likely used for development, testing, or internal access to hosted services. - **Status:** Light usage (~780 B), so probably not accessed often. --- ### **5. VPN Routing Rule** ``` Protocol: IPv4 * | Source: Route_Out_Over_VPN | Destination: * | Gateway: PROTON_VPN_VPNV4 ``` - **Purpose:** Routes any traffic from the alias `Route_Out_Over_VPN` out through the Proton VPN gateway. - **Effect:** Selectively routes certain LAN clients or services over the Proton VPN tunnel. - **Status:** 2 states, using ~5.20 MiB. --- ### **6. Default allow LAN to any (IPv4)** ``` Protocol: IPv4 * | Source: LAN net | Destination: * ``` - **Purpose:** Catch-all rule for **IPv4** traffic from LAN to go anywhere. - **Effect:** If no prior rule blocks or routes it, this rule allows all other IPv4 traffic from LAN. - **Status:** 125 states, 92.57 MiB ‚Äî lots of usage here. --- ### **7. Allow LAN to WAN net** ``` Protocol: IPv4 * | Source: LAN net | Destination: WAN net ``` - **Purpose:** Specifically allows LAN traffic to `WAN net` (your WAN interface subnet). - **Effect:** This may be redundant if the "LAN to any" rule above already permits this. - **Status:** 0 usage ‚Äî likely not needed unless you segregate WAN net intentionally. --- ### **8. Default allow LAN to any (IPv6)** ``` Protocol: IPv6 * | Source: LAN net | Destination: * ``` - **Purpose:** Allows **IPv6** traffic from LAN to any destination. - **Effect:** Needed if your LAN clients use IPv6. - **Status:** 0 usage ‚Äî possibly because you don‚Äôt have IPv6 enabled or in use. --- ### Summary You currently have: - An **anti-lockout** rule (can‚Äôt be disabled unless you turn off the feature). - A **pfBlockerNG block** rule for malicious addresses. - **Selective allow** rules for internal networks: TrueNAS and WebServers. - A **custom routing rule** for specific traffic to go out through Proton VPN. - **Default allow** rules for both IPv4 and IPv6. - One **redundant-looking rule** (LAN to WAN net) that may be unnecessary. --- Would you like help visualizing this assignment as a table or drawing, or optimizing the ruleset for better security or performance?

User: yes, I would like to see a table

Assistant: Here is a table summarizing the LAN.net firewall rules as configured in your pfSense+ system. Let me know if you‚Äôd like this exported, visualized in a diagram, or compared against best practices for VLAN segmentation or zero-trust principles.

Leftover Pizza Storage Guide

System:

User: If I purchased a pizza from a pizza parlor and stored the leftovers in the refrigerator, how long would it ge good to eat>

Assistant:

Assistant: Leftover pizza stored properly in the refrigerator is generally safe to eat for **3 to 4 days**. Here are some tips to make sure it stays safe and tasty: ### ‚úÖ Storage Tips: - **Refrigerate within 2 hours** of the pizza being cooked (or 1 hour if the room is hot). - Store it in an **airtight container** or wrap slices tightly in foil or plastic wrap. - For best quality, keep your fridge at or below **40¬∞F (4¬∞C)**. ### üçï Before Eating: - If you're eating it cold, make sure it smells and looks okay‚Äîno funky odors, slime, or discoloration. - If reheating, heat it to at least **165¬∞F (74¬∞C)** to kill any potential bacteria. If it's been more than 4 days, it's safest to toss it‚Äîeven if it looks okay. Want a great way to reheat it so it stays crispy instead of soggy?

Boise State Tuition Costs

System:

User: How much does a year of education cost at Boise State University??

Assistant:

Assistant: ÓàÉThe cost of attending Boise State University for the 2024-2025 academic year varies based on residency status and living arrangements.ÓàÑÓàÜ **Tuition and Fees:** - **Idaho Residents:** ÓàÉ$9,048 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ - **Non-Residents:** ÓàÉ$27,788 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search0ÓàÅ **Additional Estimated Expenses:** - **Books and Supplies:** ÓàÉ$800 annually.ÓàÑÓàÜ - **Food and Housing:** - ÓàÉOn-Campus: $14,884 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ - ÓàÉOff-Campus: $13,634 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ - ÓàÉLiving with Parent(s): $6,482 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ - **Transportation:** - ÓàÉOn-Campus: $2,808 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ - ÓàÉOff-Campus: $2,900 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ - ÓàÉLiving with Parent(s): $2,256 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ - **Personal and Miscellaneous Expenses:** ÓàÉ$3,652 annually.ÓàÑÓàÜ ÓàÄciteÓàÇturn0search0ÓàÅ **Total Estimated Cost of Attendance:** - **Idaho Residents:** - ÓàÉOn-Campus: $27,692 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ - ÓàÉOff-Campus: $26,534 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ - ÓàÉLiving with Parent(s): $19,190 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ - **Non-Residents:** - ÓàÉOn-Campus: $46,532 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ - ÓàÉOff-Campus: $45,350 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ - ÓàÉLiving with Parent(s): $38,190 per year.ÓàÑÓàÜ ÓàÉThese estimates are subject to change and may vary based on individual circumstances.ÓàÑ ÓàÉAdditionally, Boise State University offers various scholarships and financial aid options that can significantly reduce these costs.ÓàÑ ÓàÉFor the most accurate and up-to-date information, it's recommended to consult Boise State University's official resources.ÓàÑÓàÜ

Lost Ham License Copy

System:

User: How can I get a copy of my Ham radio license since I lost it?

Assistant:

Assistant: You can easily get a copy of your ham (amateur) radio license through the FCC. Here's how: --- ### üñ•Ô∏è **Online (Most Convenient Way)** 1. **Go to the FCC License Manager:** [https://wireless2.fcc.gov/UlsEntry/licManager/login.jsp](https://wireless2.fcc.gov/UlsEntry/licManager/login.jsp) 2. **Log in using your FCC Username and Password** - If you don't remember your login, you can recover it at [https://apps.fcc.gov/cores/userLogin.do](https://apps.fcc.gov/cores/userLogin.do) 3. Once logged in: - Click **"My Licenses"** - Find your **amateur radio license** - Click **‚ÄúDownload Electronic Authorizations‚Äù** on the left - Select your license, then click **‚ÄúDownload‚Äù** to get a PDF copy --- ### üì¨ **Need a Paper Copy Mailed?** The FCC no longer mails paper licenses by default, but you can request one: 1. While logged into the License Manager, click **"Set Paper Authorization Preferences"** 2. Choose the option to receive printed licenses by mail --- ### üìû **Need Help?** - **FCC Support**: Phone: 877-480-3201 Hours: Weekdays 8 AM‚Äì6 PM Eastern - Or you can contact a **Volunteer Examiner Coordinator** (VEC), like the ARRL, for assistance. --- Want help finding your call sign or login info? I can walk you through that too.

User: My call sign is AG7OB. I have lost my license, and I did not have or remeber my FCC login information. I created a new login with my email address and password, but I need top associate my FRN number, which I cannot locate. How can I find my FRN number?

Assistant: No problem! You can recover your FRN (FCC Registration Number) by searching for your call sign in the FCC database. Here's how to do it: --- ### üîç **Find Your FRN Using Your Call Sign (AG7OB)** 1. Go to the **FCC Universal Licensing System (ULS) License Search**: [https://wireless2.fcc.gov/UlsApp/UlsSearch/searchLicense.jsp](https://wireless2.fcc.gov/UlsApp/UlsSearch/searchLicense.jsp) 2. In the **"License Search"** form: - Enter your call sign: `AG7OB` - Click **"Search"** 3. Click on your name/call sign in the results. 4. On the **License Detail** page, look for: - **FRN:** It will be listed near the top of the page. --- ### ‚úÖ Once You Have the FRN: Now that you‚Äôve created a new FCC CORES account (with your email and password), you need to **associate your old FRN with your new login**. --- ### üîó **Associate Your FRN with Your New FCC CORES Account** 1. Go to the CORES system: [https://apps.fcc.gov/cores/userLogin.do](https://apps.fcc.gov/cores/userLogin.do) 2. Log in with your **new username (email)** and password. 3. Click **"Associate FRN"** on the left sidebar. 4. Enter: - Your recovered **FRN** - The **FRN password** (also known as the FCC Registration PIN). If you don‚Äôt remember it, click **"Forgot FRN Password"** on that page. --- ### üÜò If You Can‚Äôt Recover the FRN Password: You can request a reset or submit a request to the FCC to gain access: - Fill out FCC Form 161 or contact the FCC: - üìû **877-480-3201** (Option 1) - üìß Or open a help request here: [https://www.fcc.gov/wireless/support](https://www.fcc.gov/wireless/support) --- Want me to look up your FRN for AG7OB and give it to you here? I can do that too.

Email to JJ Request

System:

User: I have recently read a story that was written by an author in Scotland. The short story was written in 2011. The story was meant to be an ongiong series but the author experienced a life changing event that prevented him from continuin the storyline. I would like to contact him directly, by email to wish him well and to inquire as to if he ever intends to continue the series or if another author has inquired about taking up the sries based on his characthers and storyline Here is JJ's post that explains the reason for stopping the series: "Since I posted Threads: The Island on Literotica for you all to read and hopefully enjoy I have been incredibly touched and frankly overwhelmed by the stream of supportive comments and kind words from so many of you over the last 9 years. Sadly, not long after posting the story I became seriously ill." Can you suggest a note to him based on my description and his last post? I have since undergone over twenty surgeries, been hospitalized dozens of times and been on more medical treatments than I can count. As you can imagine this had a massive impact on my mental health and I lost interest in any creative pursuits, and I also withdrew from all the friends I had made along the way. 9 years on my life is gradually getting better. At this stage I can't say if I'll ever pick up the Threads stories I wrote so long ago and get them out to you all, but I wanted to say this. Thankyou for every message, every email, every comment and every forum post asking after me, wishing me well, or sharing how much any of you enjoyed my writing. During those times when I was able to read any of them I was honestly overwhelmed by everyone's kindness. I can't say what the future will bring, but I will never forget the response of so many of you who read and enjoyed my work. Thanks,

Assistant:

I recently re-read *Threads: The Island* and was struck once again by the depth of your characters, the immersive world you created, and the emotional resonance woven through your writing. It truly left an impression, and it‚Äôs clear from the comments and messages you‚Äôve received over the years that I‚Äôm far from alone in that sentiment. I came across your post sharing what you've been through, and I just wanted to reach out‚Äînot with any expectations, but simply to thank you for the work you *did* share. I'm deeply sorry to hear of the challenges you've faced. Your honesty and courage in sharing your story were as moving as your writing itself. If and when you ever feel inclined to return to *Threads*, I can assure you there is still an audience out here who would welcome it with open arms.
